TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to yesterday's announcement by the Minister for Finance that funds for several of the Government's key programs are about to run out and that the Government intends to introduce a new Appropriation Bill today to correct this situation. Why is the Government considering this unprecedented action of introducing another Appropriation Bill and amending Appropriation Bills already in the Parliament at this time? Why did the Government not know about this funding crisis when it introduced the additional appropriations—Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4)—only four weeks ago? Is the proposed action necessary because the normal channel of funds for temporary funding purposes—the Advance to the Minister for Finance—has been used up for other purposes? How can the Government have been able to appropriate $317m for a Wills by-election one-off family allowance bribe but not be able to provide for necessary ongoing funds for child-care, the aged and the unemployed?
—First of all, let me comment on Senator Short's desperate final suggestion that the one-off payment to families was a Wills by-election bribe. Let me say that the date—
—To be paid nine days before the by-election.

—Senator Short can work that out now in retrospect—very smart. But he ought to have thought about it a few months ago when a decision was made by the Government to have that allowance payable on 2 April. No date had been fixed for any by-election at that time. So do not try to get any silly electoral comfort out of this. This is for the benefit of families across Australia and families across Australia will benefit from it and they will recognise it.

PARA.TAB: It is really descending to the bottom of the barrel to make that suggestion. I assure the honourable senator that nothing like that was even contemplated at the time the One Nation statement was prepared. Senator Short, who spent his weekend tramping around Wills—most of the people were sensibly out when he called, I gather—should have spent a bit more time on that than raising this sort of issue in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know how to get there or where it was.

—I am sorry; that is quite wrong. In so far as the question had any substance at all to it, let me say that funding for the three items included in the urgent Bill, which was discussed with Senator Short yesterday, cannot wait for the passage of the normal Additional Estimates Bills in early June. The reason for that is that there has been a blow-out in funding and the Bill brings forward—
—That is right.

—That is right. The Bill brings forward expenditure originally included in the Additional Estimates Bills, with the exception of some additional funding for child-care. The need for this urgent Bill has arisen because the three programs involved are demand-driven personal benefit entitlements funded from annual appropriations. Hence, there is always a risk that actual demand may differ from the best estimates made at the time of the Budget. Failure to take action could deny eligible recipients of these programs their entitlements until after the passage of the Additional Estimates.

PARA.TAB: In regard to that part of Senator Short's question which related to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, I will obtain some advice on that from the Minister and provide it to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister's answer has not covered any, I think, of the questions that I asked. I repeat: what is different today from the situation four weeks ago when the additional Appropriation Bills were brought in, given that there has been no delay at all in the progressing of the consideration of those Bills through the Parliament? Does the Minister not agree that the situation that the Government has allowed develop in this matter is simply another stark example of its gross economic and budgetary mismanagement?

—I do not know what Senator Short thinks Question Time is about, if he thinks I am going to agree with that proposition. I am sorry to say that he is wrong. In so far as the first part of the supplementary question is concerned, additional information has been made available to the Government by the Department of Finance and that is the reason for this legislation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask the Minister whether he can comment on the response of business to the improved depreciation arrangements announced in the Government's One Nation economic statement. Can the Minister outline to the Senate the further improvements made to those arrangements and announced by the Treasurer yesterday? Finally, I ask the Minister whether he can comment on any criticisms made of the One Nation depreciation regime for new investment?

—Senator Faulkner is astute in these matters. He is already aware of the statement made yesterday by the Treasurer in relation to the improved depreciation schedule announced in the One Nation statement. This can be done on a straight line basis as well as on a declining balance basis, which was the decision announced in the statement. That change has been introduced to provide flexibility to firms in respect of their accounting. The straight line rates to apply will be two-thirds of the declining balance rate for each of the effective life classes.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday there was a comment by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald on the changes to the depreciation allowance announced in the One Nation statement. The first thing I want to say about the changed depreciation allowance and the improved investment climate is that the decision makers—from the Chief Executive of BHP, to the Chief Executive of the ANZ Bank, to Mr John Elliott, a former President of the Liberal Party—have all approved and applauded these changes. They are the people who have to write the cheques in respect of investment and they are on record as supporting the One Nation statement. As I said, yesterday Mr Gittins was on record as making some comments about these changes. The point he makes, I suppose, is the conflict in respect of the business decision makers, who suggest that the right balance was found but who are self-seeking in terms of changes to the tax system. Of course, in part, that is true because businesses have to be concerned about the taxation environment in which they operate.

I think the One Nation statement has the right balance between these two things. The depreciation rates and the development allowance in the One Nation statement are not a response to the business cycle; they are there to address structural issues. The point of the improved investment allowance is not so much to satisfy the peculiar requirements of Australian business. If the economy of Australia is to be internationally competitive, both in this country in terms of import replacement and attracting investment and overseas in terms of exports, then we have to have a competitive depreciation regime. Anybody who has done any work on this issue or made any study of it knows that we did not have a competitive depreciation regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had a better one under Fraser.
—No, that was full of distortions, Senator.
—That is what Peter Walsh said.

—That is what I say too, Senator. Peter Walsh and I are in agreement on that issue. The regime does provide a competitive depreciation regime and it has to be so. People who talk about a level playing field internationally must recognise that if we are to attract investment in this country, when decisions are made in corporate capitals in Europe and North America people will look at the taxation environment for business as one of the prime considerations—
—Have you just realised this?

—No, I have not just realised it. I am surprised that Senator Hill interjects because the Oppositions's Fightback statement says that if it gets into government it will have a look at this issue; it will have an inquiry into it two years down the track.
—That is not what it says.

—It is what it says—two years down the track. Senator Short knows that. He can try to gloss over it now if he wants to but that is essentially what it says. It is an issue which is not seriously addressed in the Fightback statement. Senator Hill interjects that he made a speech last week telling us that this was important and therefore we have acted on it. Like everybody else in the Opposition, he is a bit out of phase with his timing; he has probably started to read One Nation and realise that it is important.

PARA.TAB: This question of a competitive international taxation regime is very important for us. It is very important to any economist like Ross Gittins, as it ought to be, in terms of the international competitiveness of the Australian business sector and particularly the export sector. It is for that reason that it was done.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is it a fact that a number of key labour market programs for the unemployed are seriously underspent to date and that the latest DEET projection to the end of the financial year shows that the Jobstart wage subsidy program will be underspent by $44m, the Jobtrain program for the long term unemployed will be underspent by $5m and the job skills wages program will be underspent by $20m? Given this forecast underexpenditure of $69m on labour market programs, why is it that this afternoon the Minister for Finance will be seeking a further $87m for such programs when, despite the fact that there are already one million Australians unemployed and expenditure on these programs is the lowest per unemployed person since 1982, the Government is unable to spend the amount already allocated?

—This is an odd question coming from the Opposition, which in its consumption tax package wishes to remove virtually all the labour market support programs to help the unemployed and introduce a scheme which now is well known in the community as `Auslave' because it is aimed at reducing wages and not providing training for young workers. I am not able to confirm the estimates or the figures given to me in this question by Senator Alston. I will seek advice from the Minister, Mr Beazley, and reply in due course.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation aware of a report by the International Civil Aviation Organisation of a world downturn in airline traffic last year? Will he indicate the implications for Australia, given the importance of the aviation industry to the Australian economy?

—I am aware of the recent ICAO report, which indicated that, according to preliminary estimates, total aviation traffic in 1991 was down 4 per cent and international traffic was reduced last year by 5 per cent. The ICAO report went on to say that this was the first time since the 1940s that world schedule traffic had shown a decline. This is symptomatic of the current international problems of recessed economies, which have impacted in an international sense on this industry.

PARA.TAB: However, I am pleased to report that the picture in Australia is quite different, with 1991 proving to be a record year for total traffic in Australia, due mainly to the effects of domestic deregulation. Domestic passenger numbers for 1991 were up nearly 30 per cent on the previous year and even outstripped traffic growth in the previous record year, 1988, when high traffic was generated by Expo and bicentenary events.

In the year ended 31 December 1991, a record 16.7 million passengers were carried in Australia. I am also advised that domestic passenger numbers for January 1992 were up 20 per cent on the previous year, demonstrating that the benefits of deregulation are continuing to be taken up by the Australian travelling public.

On the international scene, Australian preliminary international passenger and freight figures for 1991 indicated a level of traffic almost equal to the record levels achieved in 1990. This was despite the substantial negative impact on traffic as a result of the Gulf war. With the changes to aviation policy outlined in the Government's economic statement, these levels of aviation activity and the commensurate benefits for Australian consumers, the tourist industry and the economy will be further enhanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that, with 19 per cent unemployment, the electorate of Wills has the highest unemployment rate in Australia and that youth unemployment has reached 50.6 per cent? Is he further aware that in Wills over 600 jobs were lost during the past 12 months due to factory closures and retrenchments in the textile, clothing and footwear industry alone and that a further 2,000 TCF jobs are at risk? Is he prepared to put a stop to further tariff cuts and to undertake a review of the TCF plan in consultation with unions and employers to stop further job losses in this crisis situation?

—I am aware that the electorate of Wills has a high level of unemployment; I do not believe it to be the highest. This morning I met with members of the Northern Region Commission, which is a group of shire councillors who represent many of the shires in the electorate of Wills. We had a long discussion about the reasons for this level of unemployment in the electorate. Certainly the recession is one of them.A second reason is the fact that there has been a reliance very much on firms in what I would describe as more traditional industries in that electorate compared with, for example, south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne where new industries are much more prevalent than in the region covered by the Northern Region Commission. There are other reasons, such as the inability of the region to attract new industries to date.

PARA.TAB: As far as the job losses in the textiles, clothing and footwear sector are concerned, I do not know the exact number. Senator Spindler referred to a figure of 600 in his question. A figure of 450 was presented to me this morning by the Region Commission. I do not know the exact number but I know that, as in other sectors, the recession has cost jobs in this sector.

I make the point that while, at the end of last year, employment in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry had declined by 14 per cent, in the financial sector it had declined by 24 per cent, in the metal trades industries by 17 per cent and in some other sectors of the economy the figures were higher than that—but lower than the financial sector, which was the top figure. The figures were considerably higher than the TCF sector. I think that has to be borne in mind when looking at those figures.

I understand the motivation for Senator Spindler's question. The chairman of the employer body in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry has been advocating support for the Australian Democrats in the Wills by-election. In that sense, I understand the motivation for the question. But knowing the traditional voting behaviour of the chairman of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry in Victoria, I doubt whether he would vote for the Democrats—I think he would be more inclined to vote for somebody else. He is prepared to advocate a vote for the Democrats in this by-election.

The Government has set out a program of tariff reductions and other assistance to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry to the year 2000. That will result in assistance to this industry this year being something like 10 times what it is for the manufacturing industry generally; in 1996 it will be eight times what it is for the manufacturing industry generally; and in the year 2000 it will be something like eight to 10 times what it is for the manufacturing industry generally.

The alternative which the industry is confronted with is having no tariffs at all, if the shadow spokesman can be believed. He believes that wonderful things will happen for this industry and other industries as a result of the program announced by the Opposition. I make it quite clear that I do not believe in that. I believe that the Government was wise and sensible to allocate money in the One Nation package to support firms in the process of restructuring in this industry. The Government will be doing that. A considerable amount of money was allocated in the One Nation statement for that purpose.

I think the people in the electorate of Wills have a stark choice. This is an area where there is a stark choice. I do not know what choice the Democrats are offering, but I doubt that it will be a viable one for this country or for this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try running on your record.

—Whatever record the Government runs on, I am fairly confident about the outcome of the race; so Senator Crichton-Browne should not worry too much about that. In so far as the last part of the question is concerned, the answer is no.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, I would suggest that it is of no joy to the people in Wills to say that other industries are worse off than the TCF industry.
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his question.

—The question is whether the Minister, not the Opposition, is prepared to do anything about it. Is he prepared to accept any responsibility for job losses in the TCF industry? Is it not simply a matter of assisting now, not in 10 years time, by stopping a further reduction in tariffs?

—There are a couple of things the honourable senator ought to get into his head. There will be no further reduction in tariffs in the textile, clothing and footwear industry until 1993. No unemployment in the Wills electorate results from current reductions—and there is a recession on.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—As I have said a hundred times in here, the excitement in the Opposition rises with poor unemployment figures. They are all it has to run on. But it would be a cruel hoax for the Democrats or anybody else to suggest to people in these industries that if we changed the protection regime tomorrow, suddenly there would be an outburst of employment in these industries. It is absolute rubbish and it is cruel to suggest otherwise. Senator Spindler had better not do that or he will hear about it in the course of the Wills by-election.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of the decision made at the World Administrative Radio Conference, held on 3 March 1992 in Spain, to allocate spectrum frequency for satellite voice and data telecommunications? Can the Minister advise what implications this will have for the telecommunications industry in Australia? In view of the fact that South Australia is particularly well placed to be the Southern Hemisphere's launch centre for low earth orbiting satellite systems, can the Minister also advise, firstly, whether the Australian Government has been involved in discussions with the South Australian Government and private sector to see whether Woomera's existing launch facilities can be utilised; secondly, what steps have been taken in negotiating any contract with the US iridium proposal for the use of launching facilities; and, thirdly, whether the research and development facilities incorporated in the multifunction polis will play a role in the development of satellite launching technology?

—I am aware of that conference; I think I had discussions with somebody who was at it. One of the important issues resolved by the conference in Spain was the allocation of spectrum for a new technology in which low earth orbit satellites provide global voice and data telecommunications services. That technology is already in an advanced state of development. Motorola's iridium project, to which Senator Schacht refers, is one of these proposals and Australian interests will be able to participate in these developments in a number of ways. There are opportunities for investors, satellite gateway operators, service providers, launch contractors and end users.

PARA.TAB: The use of Woomera as a possible launch site for these low earth orbit satellites has been raised by a joint venture comprising British Aerospace Australia, Auspace and Hawker de Havilland. That joint venture is called Southern Launch Vehicles. British Aerospace is the lead company in the joint venture. It has had discussions with the South Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government. Senator Schacht is probably aware that presentations were given by the Motorola Corporation and others to members of parliament last year about the use of the same or similar technology.

Both the South Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government are aware of the potential of the project. We are providing funds to the joint venture to enable it to investigate the technical and commercial feasibility of the proposal and Southern Launch Ventures is exploring several launch markets, including those associated with the iridium project. With regard to that part of the question relating to the MFP, space activity is seen as a promising component of that concept, but it would certainly have to wait a while until we get the results of this feasibility study and so on.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Redevelopment of St Marys Defence Site

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Defence seen comments attributed to various New South Wales Ministers threatening to block the redevelopment of the St Marys site in New South Wales following the decision by Australian Defence Industries to build a new ammunition plant at Benalla? Is there any justification in the New South Wales Government's claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the intention of Australian Defence Industries to close the Footscray, Maribyrnong and St Marys ammunition facilities and replace them with a state-of-the-art ammunition factory. The decision was to go to Benalla. An important aspect of this is, of course, to keep an excess capacity within this country if we are ever threatened. There was quite hot competition from a number of sites. In the end, ADI chose Benalla.

PARA.TAB: Following the announcement of that decision, we had an outburst from Minister Michael Yabsley in which he described this result as, firstly, cronyism; secondly, the Federal Government using raw political muscle; and, thirdly, blatant political interference. We then had Mr Greiner say, as reported by the local Penrith newspaper, that he was considering the blocking of the redevelopment of the St Marys site in retaliation for what he sees as political interference. He then wrote a letter to the Prime Minister and changed his tack. He said that he wanted the better cities program not to go to St Marys because he was worried about contamination of the site.

Finally, yesterday we had the planning Minister, Mr Webster, say on the ABC news that New South Wales would make it difficult for ADI to finance the new munitions plant from the sale of the St Marys land.
I stress that ADI made a unanimous and independent decision to go to Benalla. In a letter to Mr Greiner, the Chairman of ADI says:

Following a renewal of the press publicity regarding your Government's reaction to my board's decision to select Benalla as the site for a new ammunition factory, I decided I should write to you to assure you that the board's decision was unanimous, made on commercial grounds and not subject to political interference by the Federal Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is an irony in some ways that the last three board members I have appointed to ADI are all resident in New South Wales. The overwhelming activity of ADI will remain in New South Wales. I believe that the New South Wales Government's reaction is both spiteful and narrow-minded. I wonder why it was so curiously silent when New South Wales was awarded the submarine maintenance refit contracts, and when we were under enormous pressure, as Senator Panizza would acknowledge, from Western Australia to put the contract there for political reasons? We resisted that. New South Wales, of course, remained silent.

PARA.TAB: What happens if the St Marys site is not redeveloped? Firstly, this country forfeits the opportunity for a modern ammunition factory. But I think that is the minor consideration here. What Sydney will forfeit is the redevelopment of an enormous tract of land in the middle of Sydney. St Marys is 1,535 hectares in size—right in the middle of urban Sydney. We have plans for housing, for light industrial development, for recreational uses and for conservation zones in that area. What the New South Wales Government is really saying is that a model urban development for the middle of Sydney will be sacrificed out of spite.

Yesterday we witnessed the great spectacle of Nick Greiner announcing his new vision for New South Wales. What a pity he is spoiling it by being petty, provincial and petulant. It is noteworthy that at least the local government mayors of those sites that missed out treated the matter with far more graciousness and congratulated Benalla on winning.

Once again, we have seen in Sydney politics the Eastern Creek syndrome at work, but we in Defence have no intention of retaliating against New South Wales. We will continue to cooperate with the New South Wales Government, trying to vacate the land at Newington so as to enhance its Olympic bid. We will continue to press for removal of the ammunition pipeline that runs right through suburban Sydney. If New South Wales fairly wins contracts, as it did recently to do the initial flight training at Tamworth, we, as a Federal Government, will not interfere when it wins on commercial grounds. Finally, if ADI does, as I suspect it will, move its corporate headquarters to Sydney, we will not take any notice of complaints by other governments about political bias.

We are seeing the New South Wales Government trying to blackmail ADI and the Federal Government. It cannot redevelop this 1,500 hectares of land and get the money in to re-finance other defence projects. This is a very narrow-minded view taken by the New South Wales Government. If that is what the new vision is—the bovver boy tactics of Nick Greiner—pity help New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs. I refer the Minister to the statement from the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, which criticised the Federal Government's anti-dumping laws and, in particular, the effectiveness of the Federal Government's response and the delays built into the system. I also mention his strong urging that the Federal Government get its act together, and his reference to the forced sacking of 34 workers from Minproc's Gladstone plant because of dumped sodium cyanide. As part of the Anti-Dumping Authority's positive finding on dumping, dumping duties were imposed against imports from Germany, Italy, Japan, Korea and the United Kingdom, but the United States producer Du Pont was required only to give a written assurance to the ADA that it would not dump into the Australian market.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister whether such an assurance is legally binding and whether it is being monitored by Australian authorities. As prices for the United States imports have since gone below the price of $1,600 at the time of the hearing to $1,250 a tonne and now stand at $1,400 a tonne, and the product is being dumped by the same United States company, what action is the Minister taking to enforce the assurance given to the Anti-Dumping Authority?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a long and complex question. Let me say that when Minproc built that plant there was a very significant demand, because of the high levels of activity in the goldmining industry in both Australia and worldwide, for sodium cyanide which has since declined significantly, putting pressure on the suppliers of sodium cyanide here, Minproc, ICI and Du Pont, which I think are the main suppliers. We have had this discussion before, but let me make it quite clear that no anti-dumping regime can exclude all imports. There cannot be trade in a situation in which there is a trade freezing effect as a result of an over-rigorous anti-dumping regime.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the particulars of the honourable senator's question, our anti-dumping regime is as speedy now as any in the world and the penalties which it provides are as rigorous as any in the world. I am aware of the problem which Minproc currently has. That company has had discussions with me about it and I have undertaken to see whether we can find some solution to it in the next week or so, but it is not related to the anti-dumping procedures. In so far as the honourable senator's question seeks more detail, I will try to obtain an answer and provide it to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister, but in my question I asked whether a letter that was given to the Anti-Dumping Authority was being monitored and whether it was legally binding. If the product of sodium cyanide is coming into Australia at under the cost of $1,600, will the Minister concede that sodium cyanide at any price under $1,600 is being dumped?

—I am sorry, but I will not fix the price of sodium cyanide during Question Time in the Senate. I am aware of the letter which was an undertaking by Du Pont given to the Anti-Dumping Authority. I cannot immediately tell the honourable senator to what extent the contents of that letter and the performance in terms of the obligations undertaken are being monitored. As I said in my original answer, I will find that information out and let the honourable senator know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the provocative action of Associated Pulp and Paper Mills in Tasmania, which has suddenly advised its employees that various long-standing agreed conditions of employment are to be unilaterally withdrawn and which has refused any sort of negotiation with the unions about the matter. Given that APPM, part of the North Broken Hill conglomerate, is a seeker of government assistance in various ways, I ask: what has the Minister done about this confrontationist attitude of a major Tasmanian employer and what can he do to ensure that the company acts in a more reasonable fashion in the interests of both itself and its workers?

—On 3 March this year APPM gave 30 days notice that it would unilaterally withdraw from all over-award agreements with unions covering employees of its company in Tasmania and that it would not open discussions with those unions which represented those employees; it would only talk about this matter direct with the employees of the company itself.

PARA.TAB: The unions in Tasmania have described this as a `Robe River tactic'. They have described it thus, no doubt, because APPM is a member of the North Broken Hill group, of which Robe River is of course a subsidiary company. The tactics being employed on this occasion bear some resemblance to what occurred in the initial stages of the Robe River dispute.

The matter of working conditions and an enterprise agreement were before the Industrial Relations Commission before Deputy President Munro. He had asked the parties to pursue negotiations between themselves to settle these issues.

Because of this unilateral withdrawal from the over-award agreements and the darkening industrial clouds in Tasmania, my office contacted both the ACTU on behalf of the unions and APPM on behalf of the company and asked them whether they had any current plans to proceed with the encouragement of Deputy President Munro and join discussions to settle these issues. The ACTU replied that it did and it has been seeking talks. APPM replied that it did not and that it did not intend to meet the unions.

On the basis of that response, last Friday I wrote to Deputy President Munro acting on the public interest provisions of the Industrial Relations Act and asked him to call the parties before him in a conference in order that what is clearly a situation of industrial conflict could be brought within the proper channels of the Industrial Relations Commission and dealt with by the Commission. My understanding is that Deputy President Munro has now contacted the various parties and that the actions of the Commission have swung into play in order to try to bring about a resolution to this matter.

The Government's response is not to judge the circumstances in this case but really to encourage the parties to talk to one another, to try to settle the issue, to have resort to the Commission and, if they themselves voluntarily do not make the application, to be required to have resort to the Commission to bring about a settlement.

I conclude this answer by saying that one ought to contrast our actions of public responsibility in this case with what would have been the case had there been an Opposition government and had there been its rule of industrial law. The Commission would have been set aside and would be able to be accessed voluntarily only if both parties agreed. If one party held out, there would have been no access to the umpire in its case. The rule of the jungle would have prevailed. In the case of workers in Tasmania and at APPM, the following situation would have applied: `Do as we tell you or face the sack'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of the most recent revelations about Iraq's extensive chemical weapons program and continuing reports of the spread of chemical weapons in the Third World, will the Minister tell the Senate what the Government is doing to ban these particularly abhorrent weapons of mass destruction? What particular steps has he initiated and what timeframe can he give for addressing these proposals?

—As has been well known, the conclusion of the global convention to outlaw chemical weapons and eliminate existing stockpiles has been a fundamental objective of Australian foreign policy for some years. We have been pursuing the issue of chemical weapons through a number of other regional and related initiatives, including the holding of the government-industry conference here in 1989.

PARA.TAB: However, our judgment has been that, notwithstanding almost 20 years of discussion and negotiations by the international community at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, where the actual treaty text is being negotiated, there was a real unlikelihood of agreement being reached in the near future unless some major new external stimulus was applied to the negotiating process.

Accordingly, after quite a lot of thought and attention by my Department over the past few months, I presented to the conference in Geneva last Thursday a complete revised draft text prepared by Australia with the aim of accelerating those negotiations to completion this year. The text contains, in fundamentally reshaped form, the results of the negotiations so far agreed in Geneva, but breaks major new ground in setting out in the form of a finished treaty text what we believe are the most credible compromises available for the some 20 per cent of remaining outstanding issues.

The effort involved in preparing this text—because it is an extraordinarily complex convention and if achieved will be the most substantial multilateral disarmament agreement ever reached—was a really outstanding one. I want to take this opportunity to thank the team of officers in my Department who laboured long and mightily to produce it, and also for the consultations in which they have engaged, which have extended to some 33 capitals over the past two or three months. I make those points in the light of the sniping and carping criticism that is so often heard of my Department and the quality of the professional officers in it. I think they are a great credit to this nation.

I believe that our text does represent a watershed in the negotiations by demonstrating in particular that agreement is achievable and realistic within the timeframe of the next few months. In this respect, I was very much heartened by the response within the conference to the initiative. More than half of the CD membership—23 of the other 38 countries involved—responded to the initiative on the day, which is an unprecedented number to respond in any session. Almost all of those were openly positive in their response to the Australian proposal. A couple were studiously neutral; none was negative.

My discussions indicated that there is clear and widespread appreciation of the potential of the Australian text to take the matter forward to final agreement and to accelerate it, and I simply hope that is what happens. I do not want to get too excited at this stage because there is still some distance for the negotiations to go; but Australia certainly can be pleased with the results that have been achieved to date.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Newman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 5 March 1992:

1. Can the Minister confirm that under the provisions of Medicare a safety net operates to ensure that over the course of 12 months no Australian is required to pay more than $246 in gap payments for medical services?
2. Can the Minister also confirm that this 12 month period has recently been changed from a July/June financial year to a January/December calendar year?
3. Is it true that as a result of this change some Australians are now being required to pay up to $492 over the 12 month period before the safety net provisions come into effect?

Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question:

1. Yes. The Medicare safety net applies for the calendar year commencing on 1 January of any year and ending 31 December of that year. From 1 January 1992 the safety net threshold of $246 was extended to cover families as well as individuals.

2. Yes. The safety net provisions were changed late last year from a financial year to a calendar year basis. These changes were applied retrospectively to 1 January 1991 to facilitate the changes as they applied to the individual over the transitional period. The introduction of a calendar year basis brought the Medicare safety net into line with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme safety net and enabled the early introduction of the family based safety net.

3. No. In the calendar year 1991, no individual had to pay more than $246 in "gap" costs (ie the difference between the schedule fee or fee charged, whichever is the lower, and the benefit payable) before safety net provisions came into effect. Similarly, in the calendar year 1992, no individual or registered family will have to pay more than $246 in "gap costs. With the change to a calendar year and a family basis for the safety net, transitional provisions were introduced to facilitate the changes for individuals in the 1991 calendar year. Any out of pocket costs, up to the schedule fee, that were incurred at any time during 1991 were counted for safety net purposes in 1991. The Health Insurance Commission has been notifying anyone who paid at least S246 in "gap" costs during this period and refunding the "gap" amounts incurred in excess of that $246. Because of the change to a calendar year many individuals will receive extra benefits for medical services in 1991.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations Amendment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 78, I give notice that it is my intention at a later hour this day to withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the disallowance of the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321 and made under the Freedom of Information Act 1982. I seek leave to make a short statement about the consideration of these regulations by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Senator Bishop—Pursuant to standing order 78, I indicate to the Senate that I do not wish Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 relating to the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321 to be withdrawn. Accordingly, I require that my name be put on the notice of motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1991, I gave notice of a motion of disallowance of the regulations. I also incorporated in Hansard a statement of the concerns of the Committee. These concerns related to certificates, issued under the Freedom of Information Act, which conclusively determine that material in documents is exempt from public disclosure under the Act. These certificates may cover material relating to national security, defence or international relations; relations with the States; Cabinet; the Executive Council; or internal working documents—a relatively narrow range of sensitive material.

PARA.TAB: The regulations provide that these certificates remain in force for five years, although they may be revoked earlier by the Minister or senior officials. The period of five years appeared excessive, and there was no procedure under which a member of the public could request revocation, with AAT review of any refusal. The explanatory statement, which we understand was prepared in the Department, gave no explanation of why five years was chosen or why there were no apparent procedures for public participation in revocation.

The Committee wrote to the Minister with its concerns and received a helpful reply, the quality of which was in contrast to the explanatory statement. The Minister advised that the purpose of the regulations was to effect aspects of the Government's response to a 1987 report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation. That report had recommended two years duration for conclusive certificates. However, the Government response to the report was that two years was not long enough, but that a reasonable duration should be prescribed. The Government also accepted that regulations should clarify the power to revoke certificates.

This reply from the Minister put the matter into its correct context and enabled the Committee to focus on the main issues. The Committee then asked the Attorney whether officials of the Department could brief the Committee. However, the officials were singularly unable to provide any real reasons to justify the longer period. Indeed, the Committee was told that the Department was unaware of the notice of motion of disallowance upon these regulations, even though it had been on the Notice Paper for three months.

This seemed to indicate certain defects of management. If the explanatory statements had been of acceptable quality, and if the Department had noted the serious reservations of the Committee about the regulations, time and resources could have been saved. In the event, the Committee has now agreed to accept the regulations, despite some fairly serious misgivings. One reason for accepting is that if the regulations were disallowed the previous position would continue and conclusive certificates would remain in force indefinitely. At least these regulations are an improvement on the previous position, although not to the same degree as we would have wished and not to the extent recommended by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

In this case there was one view in the Committee that half a loaf was better than none and that none of the principles under which the Committee operates had been breached to the extent that disallowance could be justified. There was another view that concerns of the Committee had not been adequately addressed by the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy. The Committee is grateful for the courteous assistance it has received from the Attorney-General during his consideration of this matter. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard.
Leave granted.

Dear Senator Giles
Thank you for your letter of 12 December 1991 concerning the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321.

The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its 1987 Report on the Operation and Administration of the Freedom of Information (FOI) Legislation recommended that conclusive certificates issued under the Freedom of Information Act 1982 remain in force for two years only from the date of issue. In responding to the report the Government rejected this recommendation as it considered that the period of two years was too short. Many documents do not lose their sensitivity in such a short period. The Government accepted, however, that certificates should cease to have effect after a reasonable period and proposed that this period should be specified in regulations made under the Act. Regulation 5A implements this proposal by specifying 5 years which is considered an appropriate period. Prior to the amendment of the Act and the Regulations, certificates remained in force indefinitely.

Where a certificate is issued an applicant for documents already has a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The AAT has the power to determine whether reasonable grounds exist for the claims made in the certificate and to recommend the revocation of a certificate. A Minister who fails to follow such a recommendation is required under section 58A to;
. notify the applicant of the Minister's decision including all material findings of fact and reasons for decision; and
. table a copy of that notice in each house of Parliament within 5 sitting days.

The practical effect of an FOI request or an application to the AAT is the review of the continuing need for the certificate. Where the certificate is not revoked, a review will be required to advise the Minister whether, in the event that the AAT determines there are no reasonable grounds for the claims made in the certificate and the certificate should be revoked, the Minister should accept the recommendation or reject it.

In addition to the specific review procedures there is nothing to prevent the revocation of a certificate within the 5 year period and the procedure for doing so has been clarified by the new regulation 5B which was introduced at the same time as the 5 year period in regulation 5A.

Finally, conclusive certificates, representing as they do concern at the highest levels that an exemption claim may be overturned by the AAT, are rarely issued. My department has always stressed in its advice to agencies, that conclusive certificates should only be issued where documents deal with matters of the highest sensitivity. I note that the Senate Standing Committee reviewing the FOI legislation in 1987 was "favourably impressed by the restraint with which conclusive certificates have been issued" (paragraph 9.4).

I refer to your letter of 28 February 1992 regarding my advice on the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321 (the Regulations) and the Committee's discussions with Departmental Officers on 5 March 1991. At that discussion the Committee sought further information on the Regulations.
You gave notice of disallowance of the Regulations which expires on 24 March 1992. I provide further information for consideration on the disallowance motion.

In relation to the expiration of a conclusive certificate after 5 years instead of the 2 years as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs the Government adheres to its view that the 2 year period is too short. However the Government has accepted the Senate Committee's recommendation that the present indefinite operation of conclusive certificates as provided by the present legislation is inappropriate.

Conclusive certificates are able to be issued only in respect of documents affecting national security, defence or international relations (s.33), documents affecting relations with the States (s.33A), Cabinet documents (s.34), Executive Council documents (s.35) and internal working documents (s.36). Such certificates are issued only at the highest levels and where the documents deal with manners of the highest sensitivity. In practice, such certificates are usually only issued where an applicant for access to the documents seeks review of the initial refusal for access and there is a concern that the exemption claim may be overturned by the AAT. The sensitivity attaching to these types of documents is not quickly reduced and to adopt the 2 years suggested by the Standing Committee would require regular re-issuing of conclusive certificates which would be an inefficient use of resources.

The 5 year period adopted in the Regulations is a compromise between, in some cases, the sensitivity being sufficiently reduced to no longer require re-issuing of the certificate and the inefficiency caused by continual reconsideration of documents. Were the Senate to disallow the provision, the result would, of course, be that the present indefinite period for conclusive certificates, would remain.

Conclusive certificates are rarely issued. Although no statistics are kept, discussions with departmental officers, which is consistent with AAT review figures, indicate that only the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet issues such certificates with any regularity. Since 1986 that Department has issued a total of only 33 certificates—5 under Section 33, 21 under section 34 and 7 under section 36 of the FOI Act.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance--February 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The February 1992 Advance to the Minister for Finance represents two characteristics of the Government that we have come to see increasingly over recent months—first, that the Government has quite clearly lost control of its financial situation and we are seeing a progressive unravelling of the Budget day by day; secondly, that the policies of the Government are causing suffering to a large number of Australians.

PARA.TAB: So far as the financial position of the Government is concerned, it is quite clear from this statement, and from other actions, that control of the Government's finances has collapsed. We have seen today the need for the Government to introduce a special additional appropriations Bill to stop its key programs—including child-care relief, residential care for elderly persons, and various labour market programs—from running out of money in the next few weeks. Despite the fact that only four weeks ago the Government introduced the normal additional appropriations legislation, ostensibly to cover those requirements, and the fact that the normal parliamentary process of consideration of those Additional Estimates has not been delayed in any way, we find, without adequate explanation, that the situation has so changed that the Government has to introduce another special additional appropriations Bill, and, in so doing, amend the Appropriation Bills currently before the Senate in order to delete the items which will be the subject matter of the new Bill.

One of the reasons why that has happened is presumably that not enough money is remaining in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to fund those programs over a temporary period, and we are talking about a period of only a few weeks. I have spoken on this subject many times in the past in the Senate and will continue to do so. I believe that there needs to be a major review of the whole of the operations of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

It is extraordinarily difficult to discern what is happening to that fund. No consolidation of the activities of the fund is presented to the Parliament on any regular basis, other than its monthly usage, but that does not give a consolidated accumulative total of its use for the year and so on. I believe that there is a need for a considerable review and overhaul of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, certainly so far as the Senate's involvement in it is concerned. The need to draw on the Advance to the Minister for Finance to the tune of almost $27m in this month alone is testimony also to the financial budgetary incompetence and irresponsibility of the Government.

So far as the second point I raised is concerned—namely the great deal of suffering that is being caused to the people of Australia as a result of the recession caused directly, and so admitted, by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—nothing could highlight that more starkly than the fact that the February Advance requires urgent funds for emergency relief and crisis accommodation. An additional $3.5m is being sought this month alone. That is equivalent to a very substantial 35 per cent increase over the Budget and it drives home very starkly indeed the pain and the very real hardship being experienced by the people of Australia, particularly those people on low incomes, as a result of the policies of the Government.

TAB.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important report that comes before the Parliament each year. It is a report which is prepared on the instructions of the Attorney-General. As pointed out in chapter 1 of the report, division 2, part IX of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 requires the Attorney-General as Minister administering the Act to have prepared each year a report providing details concerning interceptions of telecommunications for law enforcement purposes.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, there is no doubt that the interception of telephone calls and telegrams as well—although I do not know how many telegrams are sent these days—is a very great intrusion into the privacy of people and that privacy should be interfered with only for the most serious of matters. The Act takes cognisance of that by requiring applications for warrants to be sworn and presented to higher judicial officers for permission. Of course, the difficulty is that there is no real check on the material that is set out by the authorities which are applying for the warrants. I notice in table 1 that the agencies that have applied for warrants under part 6 of the Act have included the Australian Federal Police, the National Crime Authority, the New South Wales Police, the New South Wales Crime Commission, ICAC and the Victorian Police.

In 1988-89 a total of 246 warrants were sought; in 1989-90, 340 warrants were sought; and in 1990-91, 380 warrants were sought. Very few have been refused; as I look down the list I can see only one in 1990-91 that was refused.

The swearing out of warrants has a long tradition in the process by which crime is detected. Nevertheless, we as parliamentarians have to keep constantly in mind that there is—and always will be—a problem with the application for warrants. Warrants entitle investigating authorities to take the most drastic action in some circumstances against people's privacy and against their civil rights.

Whenever a report such as this comes before the Parliament, it is appropriate that attention be paid to it and that the matter be raised, not in the sense of saying that people are not doing their job but in the sense of saying that this is a process which must be kept under surveillance—and we parliamentarians are the proper people to keep it under surveillance.

It is a great step to require investigating authorities to provide details, in terms of numbers, of the matters about which they apply for warrants. Of course, the details cannot be revealed, but the figures themselves are significant in enabling us to see whether there may be anything wrong with the process by which warrants are obtained.

Very few applications for warrants are refused. There are probably two reasons for that: first, there is no real evidence put to the contrary in the sense that there is nobody to challenge, to contradict, the evidence put forward by investigating authorities. (Extension of time granted) Secondly, by and large, the law enforcement bodies in this country—in spite of the evidence we have from time to time that they do not always act with perfection—act responsibly and with integrity in applying for these warrants.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegation to Chile and Venezuela

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Chile and Venezuela during October 1991. This delegation was very much a continuation of the delegation which attended the IPU conference. It gave us an opportunity to meet Chilean parliamentarians and members of the Ministry in Chile and to discuss in much more detail matters that are of importance to Chile and Australia. I think something that many people fail to realise is that, in many respects, Chile is a closer trading partner to Australia than the United States is because of the very short distance across the South Pacific.
—How much trade is done, Senator?

—It is actually a very interesting amount. There is less trade between Australia and Chile than there is Australian investment in Chile. Australian investment in Chile exceeds $1 billion. For example, export of sugar from Australia to Chile, taking advantage of the fact that bulk carriers—
—You are being parochial again!

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech read as follows—

PARA.TAB: This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. The main proposals contained in the Bill relate to:

SPEECH.PARA: 1)amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to provide the legislative framework for the electronic transmission to the Australian Customs Service of information concerning imported goods, and the electronic lodgement of import entries in respect of such goods;
2)amendments to the Customs Act 1901 provisions relating to the advance reporting regime for ships and aircraft and their cargo, passengers and crew, to enhance the operation of that Scheme; and

3)amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 to improve the accountability and administration of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in response to the Audit Report by the Australian National Audit Office, No. 27 of 1990-91, tabled in Parliament on 16 May 1991.
I will now refer briefly to each of those proposals:
1) Electronic Lodgement

In response to activity worldwide in the area of electronic technology and its application to international trade, the Australian Customs Service has developed and is continuing to develop a number of electronic initiatives. Both public and private sectors are seeking to standardise industry procedures by pursuing the benefits of Electronic Data Interchange (EDI), with the formation of a national communications network.

The proposed amendments in this Bill for the electronic communication and lodgement of import information are a continuation of the improvements and updating of entry facilities which were initiated by the EXIT amendments for export information, introduced into the Customs Act by Act No. 111 of 1990.

Similar to the EXIT scheme, the electronic lodgement system for imports, known as `COMPILE', will operate on the basis of legislative amendments and contractual arrangements between the Customs Service and users of the system. The proposed Principal Act legislative amendments are in a similar format and style to the successful EXIT amendments passed by this Parliament in the 1990 Budget Sittings, and will essentially introduce an electronic/computer option for the communication to Customs of information concerning imported goods, to complement the current documentary/manual entry facilities.

The `COMPILE' system includes a sophisticated regime of profiles designed to identify consignments as `high risk', `potential risk' or `low risk' for both revenue and community protection issues. These profiles can be altered by Customs to target specific types of goods or destinations and can be further refined on the basis of intelligence and data relating to importing practices. Such intelligence is received from a wide variety of sources, both national and international. The profiles may also be amended on national and regional levels and therefore are sufficiently flexible to be able to address local issues.

`COMPILE' has been programmed to ask the User a series of questions to determine the exact nature of the goods being imported. In essence the information required under both the new electronic and the existing manual regimes is similar. When the full particulars of the goods have been keyed in, the COMPILE system has the facility to react to that information and make any necessary adjustment to the risk rating which applies to the goods. Immediately after transmission of an electronic entry, COMPILE will advise the user that the entry is available for any payment of duties which might be owing, or it will require the user to present documentation relating to the transaction if a risk has been identified.

The potential savings for users in costs and time are significant. The majority of cargo is expected to be available for payment and Customs clearance in a matter of minutes after arrival in Australia. Savings in resources, staff and storage charges should be passed on to consumers in the form of cheaper commodity prices on imported goods.

The proposed amendments are intended to not only provide a more formal link between the Principal Act and the user agreement, but also to deal with other important issues which flow from the entry requirements; in particular, providing a facility to make electronic payments under protest in Section 167, amendments in respect of liability for false or misleading statements, and Customs control over imported goods.
The Electronic Lodgement amendments are dealt with principally in Clauses 13 and 16 of the Bill, and are explained in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying this Bill.
2) Cargo Reporting

The amendments contained in Clauses 8-12 of the Bill propose minor amendments to the advance reporting regime for ships and aircraft and their cargo and crew, which was introduced by Act No. 111 of 1990. The proposed amendments will enhance Customs' ability to fully risk-assess incoming cargo, crew and passengers for the detection of narcotics and other prohibited imports by ensuring that all advance reports are communicated to Customs at each port or airport of call in Australia rather than only at the first port or airport of arrival. This will ensure that Customs has the opportunity to coordinate its barrier enforcement needs whilst generally streamlining the reporting process, particularly with respect to those ships, aircraft, cargo, passengers and crew not considered to pose a high risk.
3) Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme Amendments
The amendments relating to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme are designed to streamline the present claims procedures and improve the accountability and administration of the Scheme.
The Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme provides for varying levels of rebate of either customs or excise duties to persons who purchase diesel fuel for certain prescribed off-road uses.
Categories of eligible use which are defined in the legislation include mining operations, primary production, and diesel fuel for residential premises and medical institutions.

Following an efficiency audit of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme conducted earlier this year by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO), Audit Report No. 27 of 1990-91 was tabled in this Parliament on 16 May 1991. That report identified certain deficiencies in the current administration of the Scheme.

While some of the ANAO's recommendations are still the subject of consideration by this Government, those elements in the report which are capable of immediate implementation are included in this Bill.

Clauses 28 and 46 of the Bill remove from the Customs and Excise Acts the requirement to lodge original purchase invoices with each claim. It is considered that there is no need to provide in the Principal Acts the exact documentation required to accompany claims, as this type of mechanical provision is more appropriately dealt with by regulations. During the course of 1992, the Government expects to bring on new regulations to enable invoices to be replaced by a Schedule of fuel purchases prepared by the claimant. This is broadly in accordance with Recommendation 32 of the ANAO Report.

Other amendments contained in this part of the Bill are in accord with the Government's philosophy that rebate payments be based on self assessment by claimants and that claims and claimants be subject to periodic audit.
Other Amendments

In addition to the amendments outlined above, the Bill proposes a number of minor amendments to both the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 which are explained in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 321 and made under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak in support of this motion which now stands in my name and which formerly stood in the name of Senator Giles. I point out that I move this motion in my capacity as a member of the Senate, as distinct from my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

PARA.TAB: I move this motion with an air of sadness because the history of the working of the Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been one of bipartisan support. On many occasions I have risen in this chamber to support the remarks of the Chairman and stated that we have chosen always to work in the interests of the Parliament and the making of good legislation, and in accordance with our four principles. It is disappointing that on this occasion we have come to the situation where, after a vote within the Committee, it was resolved that the Committee would move to withdraw its motion of disallowance. I then sought, as an individual senator—I stress, not as a member of the Committee—to take over the moving of the disallowance motion.

When Senator Giles rose to indicate her intention to withdraw the disallowance motion, she tabled the correspondence that the Committee had received and made a short statement. I will quote part of her short statement because it is very germane to the way in which this matter has proceeded. The correspondence and the short statement outline the fact that the matter had been treated by the Committee very seriously, and that we had sought to persuade the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that five years was too long a period for a conclusive certificate which would prevent access to documents under FOI legislation to be in place.

The position is that until this time such a certificate has been of indefinite length. But in 1987, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs presented a report on the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation. In its recommendations, the Committee said:

The FOI Act makes no provision for the expiry of certificates. The Committee is of the view that it is unreasonable for a conclusive certificate to remain in force indefinitely. One submission suggested that `an applicant should be able to apply for a review of a conclusive certificate after a period of time, say three years after the decision' to issue it. Another suggestion was that the certificate should remain in force for only two years or perhaps until there was a change of Minister. The Committee recommends that conclusive certificates remain in force for only two years from the date of issue. However, the Committee does not consider that documents should be released automatically upon the lapse of a conclusive certificate.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the Standing Committee envisaged that if it were considered necessary, the conclusive certificate could be reissued at the end of that period of two years but there would be a need for the Minister to reconsider the matter.

PARA.TAB: In the Attorney-General's letters to the Committee there was simply a statement that the Government had rejected the two-year recommendation and was imposing a five-year period. There was no real discussion or reasons given for the five-year period being adequate or satisfactory, merely a statement that two years was too little. Accordingly, the Committee asked whether officials from the Attorney-General's Department could come and meet with it and perhaps explain the background which had led the Attorney-General to come to that conclusion.

Two such gentlemen from the Department did meet with the Committee. Suffice it to say that the testimony they gave was totally and utterly inadequate. As Senator Giles said in her statement, the officials were singularly unable to provide any real reasons to justify the longer period. Indeed, the Committee was told that the Department was unaware of the notice of motion of disallowance upon these regulations even though it had been on the Notice Paper for three months. Senator Giles went on to say:

This seemed to indicate certain defects of management. If the explanatory statement had been of acceptable quality, and if the Department had noted the serious reservations of the Committee about the regulations, time and resources could have been saved.

SPEECH.PARA: And, indeed, perhaps we could have come to a satisfactory compromise and a satisfactory conclusion. But it was not until today—the last day on which the disallowance motion can be dealt with or the regulations will simply come to an end—that we were notified as members of the Committee that we should meet at lunchtime. In a briefing note we were told that since 1 July 1986 there have been only 33 conclusive certificates issued—so we are not talking about a large workload. The final statement is, `It is hoped the Attorney-General will sign a letter to the Committee this morning'.

PARA.TAB: The letter we received was undated but it was marked as being received by our Committee today. It is for that reason that Senator Lewis, who spoke earlier, voiced a feeling that all members of the Senate are entitled to be informed and that there ought to have been time for discussion. But the Attorney-General's Department was tardy in dealing with this matter. Our secretariat is here at all times, even when we are not sitting. The matter could have been dealt with. We could have been notified and, if necessary, we could have met.
I turn now specifically to the Attorney-General's letter of even date. The third paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government adheres to its view that the 2 year period is too short.
He then says:
However the Government has accepted the Senate Committee's recommendation that the present indefinite operation of conclusive certificates as provided by the present legislation is inappropriate.
By the time we get to paragraph 5, there is in my view a veiled implication in the letter which I personally do not find acceptable. It says:
Were the Senate to disallow the provision, the result would, of course, be that the present indefinite period for conclusive certificates, would remain.
Simply, those two statements do not sit together. That is a statement of fact—that when this is disallowed that will occur.

PARA.TAB: But the Attorney-General in his own letter has said that the Government has found the indefinite operation of a certificate unacceptable. Therefore, I can only expect—and, I am sure, other members of the Senate will expect—that when this existing regulation is disallowed, the Attorney-General will indeed make fresh regulations. Hopefully, he will accept the reasoning of the Committee and of individual senators that the period of five years is simply too long and that the period of two years, as recommended, certainly would be acceptable. But he may come back with another alternative—a period of three years—for which he may be able to give good reason. Indeed, he may be able to accept the reasoning, which the Committee considered, that at least the applicant or a member of the public should be able to ask for revocation of a certificate. It would not be simply a matter of the Executive—that is, the Minister himself—having a right to revoke and there being no opportunity for any member of the public affected by the certificate to make application to the Minister for him to consider a revocation.

So there are many ways in which this matter can be resolved. But simply to say, `It's five years, and that's the only thing we'll consider' is not, in my view and that of other senators, an acceptable way to proceed. It is important from the Committee's point of view that Ministers know and that members of the Senate know that at all times we, as members of the Committee, have in our minds that at the end of the day regulations must be made which are as effective as any Act of parliament. They must be just as effective in determining how people are affected by the law. Those regulations have to be properly scrutinised by the Committee in accordance with four principles. We need to ensure that individuals' rights are protected; that there is proper review; that we do not have regulations instead of legislation; and that regulations come within the confines and the power of the enabling legislation.

I stress again that in viewing the reputation and standing of the Committee and the work it does, members of the Executive and members of parliament must have those four principles paramount in their mind at all times. When we go to a member of the Executive, to a Minister, there must always be room for us to negotiate and say, `The way this regulation has been made is not serving the interests of the people; this is a better way of doing it'. I have not moved this motion in any flippant or, indeed, partisan manner. I have moved it because I believe that it is the best way to proceed. I stress again: I have moved this motion as an individual member of the Senate and not as Deputy Chairman of the Committee.

I believe that, in disallowing this regulation, we are leaving the way open for the Attorney-General to come back with fresh regulations which will mean that the interests of the individual will be served and that the freedom of information legislation will act in the way in which it was meant to in serving the interests of individual Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in looking at the issues we are discussing today, and reporting in December 1987, recommended—I think one member dissented from the recommendations—that conclusive certificates remain in force for only two years from the date of issue. That is the point being discussed currently. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) brought down regulations that meant that this time limit was five years. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances had expressed concern that that was too long. Senator Bishop has adequately outlined the process that went on in our asking to see people from the Department.

PARA.TAB: One of the things I expressed concern about was that officers of a department responsible for regulations were not aware that the disallowance motion had been on the table of the chamber. They did not seem to be aware of nor concerned about the fact that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee had expressed its concern. I have found that since I have been on the Committee, usually when the Committee goes to a Minister with a concern—and it is well thought through; we do not go in any light-hearted way to a Minister to ask for a regulation to be altered—the Minister will oblige by meeting the requirements or request of the Committee.

In this case the Minister did not. The officers did not seem very aware. One of the things we did was to allow this to continue so that we could get a response from the Minister. Senator Giles wrote to the Minister during the last sitting fortnight. When did we get the reply? We received it on 24 March.

As Senator Lewis said, because of the confidentiality and the nature of this Committee we are obliged not to show any correspondence or discuss any issues that the Committee discusses until the documentation has been tabled. As far as members of the Committee on both sides of the chamber go, those issues are not discussed. What goes on in that Committee is kept within the Committee. It is as tight as tight can be. On this occasion, when we were asked why we were expressing concern, we were not able to show our colleagues any of the correspondence today because it had not been tabled.

As Senator Bishop said, had the Minister given us an earlier answer we could have had a meeting of the Committee yesterday. We would have had time to table the documentation immediately after Question Time and at least have had some time to discuss it. But we have not had that. The whole thing has not been handled very well in terms of enabling us to do our job properly and enabling the Senate to consider the matter.

Of concern to me, and an issue that the Minister has raised, is that if the regulations are disallowed, then the present indefinite period for conclusive certificates would remain. Often the word `dilemma' is used wrongly, but I was in a dilemma on the Committee because, on the one hand, I believed that the two-year limit should obtain and, on the other hand, I faced the fact that if the regulations were disallowed the present indefinite period for conclusive certificates would remain.

One of my concerns is that one can always be held over a barrel. If a regulation is brought down that partly meets the concern or meets the concern in a time frame, you are then put in a cleft stick of saying, `I will agree with that because if I do not the situation will be worse'. It would have been appropriate for the Minister to have addressed the issue because of the overwhelming concern by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The Minister may have obliged us by re-issuing the regulations with a two-year period.

It is very sad that we have reached this point today and that it could not have been resolved by the Minister. I am equally concerned with the issue that Senator Austin Lewis raised, which is that our colleagues have not had time to look at carefully, and to come to a considered decision about, the disallowance of these regulations, all because it has not been handled sensitively and appropriately by the Minister and his officers.
