It goes to show that we still need to educate many people about the role of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It also shows that we need to be very careful that we do not set a precedent that one is held over a barrel on a set of regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to address this issue before the Senate concerning the disallowance of regulations which would ensure that conclusive exemption certificates issued under FOI legislation remain in force for five years. This is certainly an improvement on the situation before the amendment to the Act and the introduction of these regulations where these exemption certificates remained in force indefinitely. However, the Australian Democrats believe that freedom of information should mean what it says, and that individual citizens should have maximum access to government documents—maximum access, that is, that is compatible with security interests and the high level of confidentiality concerns that a government legitimately has.

PARA.TAB: In this context, the Australian Democrats agree very much with the opinion expressed earlier by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances when the Committee said that five years was too long and that two years was a more appropriate period. The Australian Democrats are not convinced by the arguments put forward by the Minister that five years is impractical. There is nothing to prevent the Minister from reissuing such a certificate when the period of two years has nearly elapsed. On that basis we believe that the balance of judgment in this issue must be in favour of citizens wishing to gain access to government documents, and I confirm that the Australian Democrats will vote in favour of the disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel very much in the position of those judges who are sometimes asked to give extempore decisions. I apologise if any of my reasoning is not quite as rigid as I might have hoped. This matter is of grave concern to me because it placed those of us who were on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in a certain bind. Most members of the Committee were very concerned that the time period provided in the regulations seemed a little long. Certainly it was longer than the period that was originally recommended in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The question, therefore, boiled down to this: should we as individuals exercise a judgment to strike down these regulations, recognising the possibility that, in so doing, the Government may not bring forward new regulations and so the old indefinite time period would remain? The question was: how was the freedom of the individual to be better served? Was it to be better served by striking down the regulations as being unsatisfactory, or was it better served by accepting them, as opposed to the otherwise existing situation?

My view is that the regulations as made and brought before the Senate were unsatisfactory. I have a major reservation here in so far as the power of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is concerned, and that is this: if the Senate were to say that a particular regulation which was of a character repugnant to some members of the Committee and repugnant to many senators could be allowed to remain in effect simply because it was better than repealing it and having an even more unsatisfactory situation, then I believe that we run the very grave risk of hamstringing not only the Senate but also a very fine Committee, the members of which endeavour as best as they can to be totally non-partisan in their views.

My concern was that, if we did this, we would effectively be saying to any government department or to any Minister who was so disposed, that a half satisfactory regulation was better than no regulation at all. Of course, that would create the precedent that Ministers or departments could bring forward delegated legislation which appeared to be permissive in character but was in fact not so permissive because it might contain other portions or other clauses in the legislation which constrained other liberties. On the one hand the regulation may grant a freedom or liberty, but on the other hand it may take away another freedom or liberty.

That would require the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to make a value judgment between one liberty and another. I do not believe that it is the proper role of that Senate Standing Committee to make that judgment. Accordingly, I thought it was unsatisfactory that the Committee should be placed in this position by the Minister and by the tardiness with which both the Attorney-General and his Department dealt with the very real concerns of the Committee. That was my first area of reservation.

These regulations are very important because, unlike the previous regulations, they recognise the principle that the effluxion of time of itself may be sufficient to release, or justify releasing, a certain matter from the scope of a conclusive certificate. That is very important because previously, when there was an indefinite period of time for which the conclusive certificate applied, it could only be released from the provisions of that conclusive certificate by virtue of a positive act—a revocation made with a residual power.

These regulations now say that the effluxion of time of itself is sufficient. If that is the case, what then is the appropriate period of time? That is why I feel that two years is more appropriate, particularly since these regulations do not allow scope for an individual to make application for review of the determination behind the conclusive certificate. For those reasons I believe that these regulations should be disallowed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that some matters have been raised by senators in this debate which need some correction in order to put the matter of conclusive certificates in proper perspective. They are granted, and granted rarely—or made rarely—by a Minister, but there is, of course, a right of appeal, so I did not understand Senator O'Chee's final remarks. Senator Bishop is wagging her head negatively in response to that proposition.
—No. I will tell you what I was wagging my head about in a moment.
—If a person is aggrieved by the decision to grant a conclusive certificate, then that person can go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
—It may only recommend.

—Of course, but that person can go to the AAT. What happens is that the AAT may make a recommendation that the conclusive certificate be revoked. The Minister then has to consider that recommendation. If the recommendation is thought to be a good one, and the Minister is convinced, then, of course, that is the end of the matter. If he does not accept the recommendation, his non-acceptance has to be tabled in Parliament and it becomes a matter for parliamentary debate. I am just indicating that there is a process there.
—Not a binding process.

—Not a binding process, no. Nevertheless, I am just dealing with Senator O'Chee's point which indicated that he thought that there was no way for the conclusive certificate to be challenged. It can be challenged, though the honourable senator may not think that it can be challenged in as strong a form as he would wish.

PARA.TAB: The practical effect of the passage of this disallowance motion—and it appears that it will be passed—will be that conclusive certificates will not have any time limit placed on them when they need to be reconsidered. The conclusive certificate is exhausted at the end of five years, but it can be the case that a new certificate is issued. What it requires is a reconsideration of the reasons underlying the granting of the conclusive certificate and to see whether those reasons still have the force that they did have, either at the time of the granting of the conclusive certificate or during the currency of that certificate.

Whilst I think it is correct, under the regulations, that there is no formal mechanism for a person to ask the Minister concerned to reconsider the matter, there is a capacity for the Minister to reconsider the matter and revoke the certificate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only by an Executive act.

—Of course, by Executive act; I do not see how else it could be done. In that situation, I am sure that any approach by an aggrieved person would trigger that reconsideration. In that situation the Minister might or might not grant the revocation sought.

PARA.TAB: We are in a very difficult situation because, as I understand it, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances determined—obviously by a majority—that it would not itself proceed with a motion to disallow—at least, not under the name of its chairman Senator Giles. We are now in a situation where some senators have exercised their rights under the Standing Orders of the chamber to take over that particular motion. As I said, the consequence will be a situation where no time limit will attach to the duration of those conclusive certificates—and sometimes half a loaf is better than no loaf, even though Senator O'Chee was right to raise some cautionary note about the precedent value of such a situation.

However, I do believe that here, where it is very difficult to say whether two years, three years or four years is the exact and best time to put as a limitation on the operation of these conclusive certificates, the Senate, in rejecting and disallowing this regulation, will create that unfortunate situation where the certificates will run on indefinitely. I do think that that is unfortunate and, obviously, the Government will have to consider its response in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I have listened with interest to Senator Tate's remarks. I am sure that he would accept that, when I shook my head at his comments concerning the availability of the appeal through the AAT mechanism, I was doing so to indicate that that is not an acceptable position. It is both a costly and lengthy exercise to get a decision, and a decision on this matter by the AAT is only a recommendation to the Minister, who then goes away and considers it again. As I said, it is both costly and lengthy.

PARA.TAB: The Committee did put to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that he ought to make provision for a concerned member of the public to make application to him to reconsider the placing of that certificate on information desired. That was rejected. However, having listened to the Minister's statement, I am sure that the disallowing of this motion today will mean that we will be reverting to the old position. I am sure that the Minister would not wish to imply that the Attorney-General is not a man of his word and is in any way not an honourable man.

Indeed, I accept his letter at face value and expect him as an honourable man to honour his statement where he says, `The Government has accepted the Senate committee's recommendation that the present indefinite operation of conclusive certificates as provided by the present legislation is inappropriate.'

The Attorney-General has himself accepted that statement, the Government has accepted it and, as I said during my first speech, I sincerely stress and hope that the Attorney-General will make fresh regulations that will take into account the very serious concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and, indeed, take into account the very serious concerns of the Senate, and bring back to the Committee a regulation or set of regulations which in fact will allow a shorter period of time and greater access to information and enable the freedom of information legislation to truly serve the purpose that it was meant to serve.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise briefly to add my own invitation to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to reintroduce those regulations in line with the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and in line with the comments made in this chamber. It is quite clear that the opinion of the Committee is that five years is not an acceptable period. It is not an acceptable period to the Australian Democrats. We believe that freedom of information regulations must err on the side of the right of the individual to obtain as much information as is feasible in the government process. Clearly, there can be differences of opinion as to the exact period that should be specified. I believe, in the light of the statements made by the Attorney-General, that it is incumbent upon him to bring back to the Senate a regulation that is acceptable to the Senate as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on clauses 4 to 6 of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1992, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Debate resumed from 4 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to talk on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill, because the Bill now before the Senate makes a number of changes to the operation of the existing child support legislation. It is designed to introduce more flexible appeal mechanisms and collection arrangements. It is designed to enhance the powers of the Registrar of Child Support to recover amounts that are outstanding and generally extend the scheme eligibility in respect of children subject to child welfare.

PARA.TAB: I would say that these changes are overdue, even though the Act itself has not been in existence for very long and certainly flexibility is required. During the course of my remarks on this Bill I will be alleging that there are a number of things wrong with the way the Child Support Agency is operating and I will be suggesting that there are things wrong with the formula upon which the calculations are made. Perhaps you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have heard me speak previously on this matter when bringing before the Senate problems that have arisen with the Child Support Act. I want to stress that, for the most part, it is legislation which we supported and which we do support, but we would like changes made to it.

In being critical of what has happened since the legislation came into operation, I am not suggesting that it should be abandoned. It has been in force now for some three years and there have been considerable successes which I will refer to, but there have been some failures. We have had the benefit of the report of Mr Justice Fogarty, Chairman of the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group, which came into the Senate only a couple of weeks ago. The report consists of two volumes which are pretty weighty and contain quite a lot to read. Mr Justice Fogarty quite rightly points out that there has been a marked changed in public attitude to child maintenance since this Act came into operation. I will quote from Mr Justice Fogarty's report where he states that the extent to which parents should support their own children compared with the responsibility of the community to do so through social welfare is significant. He also considered whether it was possible to introduce a formula for the calculation of child support liabilities and whether enforcement through the Australian Taxation Office was desirable and would be effective.

There is now an acknowledgment by the vast majority of Australians that the responsibility for the support of children should primarily lie with the parents. Mr Justice Fogarty summarised the current situation as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The debate now is not whether child support should be assessed by a formula but whether the formula in Australia is satisfactory or whether it can be improved. The debate now is not whether child support obligations should be enforced through the Taxation Office but whether its procedures need to be improved so as to become more efficient and effective.

As I said, the scheme has had considerable success. When we think back to what existed previously, it is a vast improvement. I want to refer to a few facts. The average court order for maintenance has increased from $26 per child per week in 1988 to about $42 per child per week in 1991. The average stage 2 assessment is about $49 per child per week. The number of sole parent pensioners now receiving maintenance has increased from 26 per cent to almost 40 per cent. The agency now collects and distributes over $11m each month in child support payments. The collection rate has increased from 34 per cent in the years before the scheme to 65 per cent at present. I hope it will go much higher than 65 per cent, but one cannot deny the incredible increase that has occurred. Also, there has been a significant increase in payments outside the scheme by private arrangements between parents.

PARA.TAB: In effect, in 1989-90 the scheme saved taxpayers something in the order of $35.5m. It is not the only criterion of success, but for taxpayers it is a pretty significant one. However, these successes cannot be allowed to overshadow the significant problems and distress which have been caused to a number of those involved. I would think that every member of this Parliament, in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, has been deluged with complaints, but not just coming from one side of the argument—not just those who are paying—but from both custodial parents and non-custodial parents.

I want to review now some of the problems which have arisen with the operation of this scheme. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill that was brought in in 1989 said in part that the Bill was intended to establish a scheme which ensures that access to child support is simple, timely, flexible and respects personal privacy. To an extent the Act has fallen down in relation to each of those criteria and there are considerable inadequacies which constituents have had difficulty coming to grips with. As I said, both custodial and non-custodial parents have complained about the scheme itself, the formula and its administration.

The complaints, in a sense, fall into four categories: complaints by custodial parents that the money they receive takes too long to arrive and, in many instances, is still insufficient to raise children; complaints by non-custodial parents that the formula is too harsh and too inflexible; complaints by the subsequent partners of non-custodial parents that the amount of money that a non-custodial parent has to pay has no regard for the fact that a person may wish to establish a second marriage—a second family—and get on with living; complaints by clients about the extreme difficulty in communicating with the Agency and receiving adequate and prompt responses from it.

The scheme is seen by many as inflexible and incapable of allowing for individual cases and peculiarities. Perhaps that is inevitable when one resorts to a formula. Perhaps there is no other way. The previous way of orders of the court certainly did not work from two points of view: firstly, the amount of maintenance being ordered for people to pay—and I will come back to that; secondly, the enforcement of court orders. The orders made by the court, which I referred to, were previously and frequently consent orders.

In the normal course of matrimonial proceedings one would have to say that the arrangements made for the welfare of children by parents who were formerly married should be the best arrangements and that the court ought not lightly interfere with what the parents agree to. But the fact is that from the beginning of this Act, parents made arrangements which took into account the level of social security that the custodial parent could get and kept the maintenance payment at the minimum that enabled the parent to get the maximum social security payment. Many of us who were involved in the Act for a very long time objected to that and tried to have it changed. In my opinion, that was where it all went wrong.

I think I referred to the figure of the average maintenance as being $26 a week. If one had two children and paid $26 a week, the custodial parent got the maximum amount from social security. There were times when other payments were made in addition to that and that seemed to be fairly common knowledge. In my view, the fact that the situation got as far out of hand as it finally did flowed from that.

The Law Council of Australia has raised concerns about the formula which now exists. The alternative to having a court decision or an agreed decision probably has to be a formula. I think just about all of us in this chamber agreed to the formula when it went through. We find that its operation now is not sufficiently flexible and does not take into account a number of factors which, I believe, it must. Further changes need to be made.

It does not take into account the different ages of the children being dealt with; financial responsibilities and resources; other incomes that the parties might have; the income of the custodial parent; the children's independent financial resources, perhaps—not in many cases, but in some, and that ought to be taken into account—the varying costs of accommodation which one custodial parent has to pay as against another. The formula lacks flexibility in this sense.

One of the most disturbing problems of the issues which has come before the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act—a committee on which I am currently serving—relates to these issues. The Child Support Agency is not specifically a reference before us. Certainly, in the more than 1,100 submissions that we have seen, it is the payment of maintenance—which is regarded as an unreasonably large proportion, given the fact that the custodial parent's income is not taken into account in the formula—that is the cause of a lot of the unhappiness and distress that we have heard about in recent times.

I believe that there is also in the community a low level of understanding of the formula and how it operates. I do not suggest that as a criticism of those who are complaining, but merely as a fact. I get back to the point that it is worth remembering that prior to the introduction of the child support scheme, three-quarters of non-custodial parents did not contribute to the support of their children. But I think there are still matters to be brought before the Parliament.

In this Bill there is the question of the administrative review process. The Bill will now allow for the parent liable to be paying maintenance to have an assessment of child support reviewed by an independent person free of charge. Without legal representation, the cost of having the formula reviewed by the court from when it started until now has been absolutely prohibitive. One fellow—and it is mostly men in such instances—who was attempting to pay the money that he had to pay and live did not have a cent left in his pocket to go to a court to have the maintenance reviewed. But that was his only mechanism. It was useless trying to talk to the Australian Taxation Office about it. The formula was rigid.

I hope that this will be a mechanism which will be of value. I do not know whether it will work as the Government intends or whether it will need further modification. But it is proposed to encourage parties, in a sense, to go to mediation to try to work something out. I do not know how that can happen while the formula remains rigid. What woman is going to give up maintenance that the formula presently allows her to collect? I think at some stage we need to hear a bit more about exactly how this will operate or what power the independent person will have to make a variation which is meaningful and lawful.

The Bill will also end the mandatory requirement that pensioners register for collection by the CSA an amount of child support that arises from an administrative assessment and allows a pensioner to choose to have payments made direct. It will enhance the powers of the Registrar to recover. I think we all know that for those who are on salaries from which tax is deducted—PAYE employees—it is relatively easy to get the money and require the employer of that person to pay the money directly to the Tax Office. With somebody who is self-employed it has been fairly difficult. Where a self-employed person has money in a bank account, the Registrar will be able, through this amending legislation, to garnishee other moneys in a way that will free it up and make it work more readily. Senator Alston will be moving an amendment in relation to an aspect of that, which I support, but I shall not go into it in detail at this time.

I mentioned that in the past consent orders were accepted by the court. Consent orders will now properly be subject to the scrutiny of the court. The consent order may vary the formula. But if there is a consent order, the court will look at it and make sure that it is, in a sense, in the interests of those involved on both sides. Payments made outside the agency arrangements can be taken into account more readily than at present. The enforcement of child support debts are dealt with when the person paying is not in Australia. There is a provision introduced in this Bill to set aside transactions which are designed to defeat the capacity of a person to pay.

The Bill proposes to remove the ability of pensioners to elect to end the liability of the non-custodial parent who is required to pay. It has been felt that there is a need to have an administrative method of ending liability, not merely the election of the parties. The Bill will eliminate the need for the agency to off-set liabilities that arise. It will be subject to child welfare law. They are just some of the other provisions which are included in the Bill that we are discussing.

I get back to the formula itself. It is the formula that is the subject of a considerable number of complaints to members of parliament. It is currently being used to calculate the liability of a payer. It is rigid. It does not account for the actual financial needs and circumstances of the parties. No consideration is given to a new family which may be established as a consequence.

There is a need to highlight one of the anomalies in the formula itself which is causing great anxiety. Under the formula, the custodial parent is allowed an amount of up to the average weekly earnings before his or her income is counted in the assessment. A wife, in this instance, is allowed to earn $29,931 a year or $575 a week. Then she is allowed to deduct further moneys from her income for each child that she is caring for. But the husband, the non-custodial parent, is permitted only an allowance for living expenses. In today's figures that amounts to $7,584 a year or $145 a week. In many cases, that is totally unsatisfactory. One just cannot do it; one cannot live on that sort of money.

The formula can also ignore the fact that the custodial parent may be in a relatively good financial position and not in need of such high levels of child support as would result from the direct application of the formula to the payer without regard to the circumstances of the person receiving the money. The present arrangement of appeal to the Family Court is costly and cumbersome and the legal costs are not recoverable. There is no chance that these people, left on $145 a week, could appeal; there is no chance that they could put together the money to lodge an appeal. They are left feeling very angry indeed. They are frequently quite happy to pay maintenance, quite happy to be responsible for their children, but they are treated virtually as though they are criminals because they are not able to pay and they get resentful because of it. Resentment in the breakdown of marriage is one of the things we all need to be very careful to eliminate. The Bill before us addresses these problems to an extent. It will allow for the custodial or the liable parent to have an assessment in the manner I have referred to. I hope that works well because it is necessary.

With regard to the private agreements I mentioned earlier, it will be necessary and compulsory for pensioners to register for collection. In many cases where non-custodial parents have been happy to contribute over and above the minimum required level of maintenance there have been difficulties. I will cite shortly one example that encompasses just about every aspect of the problems that so many have. The Bill provides that pensioners may choose to have child support payments made to them privately and directly, although they retain the option to register for collection by the Agency.

The Bill, I suggest, still does not go far enough in attempting to solve some of these problems. There are complaints that the formula assumes that the custodial parent has the costs of a single parent and does not take into account the fact that when that parent remarries or is living in a de facto relationship there is considerably more money in the household. The income of non-custodial parents has to drop to 85 per cent of what they previously received before there is any reduction in the maintenance they are required to pay. The fact that the formula of prescribed payments is tied in with inflation means that the non-custodial parent's income is presumed to rise in tandem with inflation, which last year we know was much greater than this year.

The final report of the evaluation of the child support scheme also draws attention to the unfairness of dividing the children of Australia between stage 1 and stage 2 by an arbitrary time line. Because nothing has been done about this situation, a substantial number of children in Australia continue to be significantly disadvantaged and many continue to live in poverty. They are not simple matters but they are matters which, I believe, still need to be dealt with.

The administration of the scheme has also brought many complaints to those of us who have been interested in the area. Incredible delays have occurred between the making of a court order and the registration of a liability with the Agency, and between the lodgment of an application for maintenance to be collected by the Agency and the receipt of the first payment to the custodial parent.

We do have something to judge this by because previously these orders were registered by the collector of maintenance and the money was collected by him and paid out. It did not take anything like as long as it has been taking over the past couple of years. The initial delay has been between eight and nine weeks, and in some cases considerably longer. A parent with several children needs the money for food, clothing, the light bill and to run the household. A delay of eight to nine weeks is absolutely intolerable; it makes it impossible to budget and it makes it impossible to run the household. Some of these delays are well understood and explained but, with so many of them on a fixed income where the money is paid in by the employer, it is inexcusable. It certainly is an area of constant complaint to my office and to others.

The other area of complaint has been the level of debt at which the Agency will intervene to enforce payment. A woman who rang my office had been trying for a long time to get the Agency to respond. She was told eventually by someone on the phone that until the debt was something like $1,500 it was not worth pursuing. For someone trying to feed and clothe a family and to run a household, $1,500 arrears of maintenance is an incredibly large sum. It told me that somebody was very out of touch indeed in dealing with people who need money to run their households.

There have been incidents of wrong information being sent to people. Hopefully, that will not happen again. It certainly is undesirable that personal information should be sent to the wrong individual; it is highly distressing. People make phone calls to the Agency. For a long time in Canberra one could get somewhere only by ringing Sydney. Certainly one could ring a 008 number, but that did not avoid the frustration of not being able to get an answer. That has been the experience not only of clients of the Agency but of all of us. People from our offices have rung and rung and got a different person every time they called.

The complaints include inconsistency in response from the Agency and, on occasions, rudeness from the staff. I believe that the staff probably have not had sufficient training for the area they are working in and that there are not sufficient of them to do the job. We have set up a very large enterprise to pay money through the Taxation Office and out in this fashion, which I said at the beginning I support; but I am not sure that we have put the right infrastructure in place to enable it to be done as it should be.

People feel that they are treated without dignity. They can never get the name of the person on the other end of the phone and ring back and feel that the same person is taking an interest in their problems. There have been errors in calculating the payments owed to parents; long delays on the telephone; long delays in getting answers to correspondence, particularly in the regional areas. Being a senator from Queensland, Mr Deputy President, you have probably experienced that as well. There have also been complaints of inefficiency in collection procedures. Many of these complaints could be corrected by adequate training of staff and adequate numbers of staff.

All of us could spend a great deal of time giving anecdotal stories of the things that have come into our office. One in particular was bizarre. An arrangement which originally had been paid regularly through the collector of maintenance—an amount paid by the former husband in excess of the court order—eventually was registered with the Child Support Agency. The Agency found that there was a credit of $1,500; that was the amount extra that the husband had been paying, had agreed to pay, had always paid, and was happy to continue to pay. The Agency told the husband that there was a credit and he did not have to pay any more for a while. He continued to pay what he had always paid because that was the agreement between him and his wife, notwithstanding a court order.

This saga goes on and on, but I shall not detail it all. Every now and again the Agency would not send her a monthly payment because, even though it had the money, it said that her payments were in credit of the court order. Phone calls were made to the Agency. The responses were: `We are working on a skeleton staff'; `Sorry, she's at lunch'; `He's sick'; `He's not on the floor today'. It just went on and on. The money was in the hands of the Agency, that is the point. It was not arrears being collected. It had been paid by the husband for the benefit of his children, but the Agency would not pass it on because it appeared to be in excess of the order. In fact, the Agency had been told very clearly that it was the amount the parents had agreed upon.

There has to be some scope for flexibility if this scheme is to work. Where people reach an agreement—for example, in this instance, to pay more—or where the father agrees to continue to pay for a child continuing on to tertiary education, the Agency should acknowledge this and not interfere to this extent. The stress caused to the people concerned, of course, is enormous. It is not a matter of any individual officer not doing his or her duty or not trying. I believe these officers are overstressed. One girl we spoke to said that she had been on the job for two days. She had inherited 200 letters, some of which were several months old. In those two days she had answered only six letters because of the number of phone calls coming in. That is the sort of pressure those in the Agency are working under. I should say that they are working under great stress. So there is stress within the Agency and enormous frustration in the community with those who are trying to deal with it and trying to get on with their jobs.

I think in what I have said this afternoon I have indicated the things that still need to be done to make the scheme work properly. I shall not go into the need for this scheme and the background to it. As I said at the beginning, it is working fairly well when we consider the amount of money that is being collected and the significantly larger numbers of children whose parents are now contributing to their support, as they should be. Let us try to run it in a way that gets rid of the frustrations that are causing so much trouble to so many people and make sure that it operates in the way that the Parliament wanted it to when it set out on this exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy today to support the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the amendments to it proposed in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill. I take note of what Senator Reid said in her contribution. Much of it would not be a matter of disagreement amongst us. But, listening to Senator Reid, one might have concluded that something more significant than just administrative procedures needed to be changed. To make it quite clear, I think Senator Reid would be in support of the basic understanding of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The criticisms of this Bill, while they are extensive, I do not think in any way jeopardise the intent of the original legislation nor suggest significant amendment to it. However, some of those administrative difficulties have led to the amendment we have here today: that is, the introduction of a new administrative appeals system so that people will not have to go back through the Family Court if they want to modify, increase or reduce the child support payments that are in place for them.

We know the difficulties of getting in and out of the Family Court, particularly in relation to delays and the challenge alluded to by Senator Reid in respect of legal costs. These are the sorts of things that make most people decide it is not worth proceeding. This amendment allowing for a simpler, less expensive and more accessible appeals procedure to modify arrangements made under child support agreements deserves our commendation and has to have the support of everybody in this place.

It is reasonable, while we are talking to this amendment, to canvass a few other issues associated with child support. It is true that it has been an area of significant complaints. Those complaints have come to most honourable senators, I should have thought, in all sorts of ways and they have their own character and colour. But I note that the character of the complaints I get about child support and the payment of maintenance has changed over the past five years. It has moved away from `I can hardly cope with the insufficiency of the payment' and `I don't get much' to `Why do I have to pay all of that?'. In other words, the complaints in large number come more from the paying non-custodial parent than from the non-receiving custodial parent.

If there is one statistic that should be held up in this legislation it is the collection rate; that is, the payment of maintenance before and after the introduction of this legislation. Before the legislation, about 30 per cent of non-custodial parents contributed maintenance payments on behalf of their children. Since the introduction of this legislation, the figure has increased to about 70 per cent. That is a very significant statistic. People were avoiding their responsibilities and liabilities under the law as a consequence of producing and parenting children, through adoption or whatever. After the introduction of this legislation, there was a dramatic increase in the number of parents who appreciated that they had better accept that responsibility.

What is also shocking is that 30 per cent of non-custodial parents are still avoiding the payment. If we say that an increase from 30 per cent to 70 per cent is worth noting, and I think it is, it is also important to remember that that still leaves 30 per cent of non-custodial parents who are avoiding their obligations. By and large, they are not avoiding them because of administrative difficulties with the Child Support Agency. They are avoiding them because they do not want to pay. They are avoiding them because they say, `We should not pay unless we have access to children'.

One of the most common confusions in the minds of people, certainly in the minds of non-custodial parents, is that if they pay maintenance they have a right to access. It is important to note that those are two quite separate issues. Paying maintenance is an obligation consequent upon having a child and it in no way buys access. Being denied access in no way reduces or removes an obligation for maintenance. As people begin to appreciate that, having had a child, they have an obligation to provide for its livelihood, its education, its housing, food, clothing and so on, we see a gradual acceptance and an appreciation of that obligation.

As I have said before in this place, one of the things that has quite shocked me is the number of non-custodial parents, very often men, who paid their maintenance obligations before this legislation was introduced and who still felt annoyed at having to do it. I used to be surprised and ask them why, if they were honourably fulfilling their obligations, they did they not join forces with those people who felt that that was an honourable thing to do and loudly go out and ask not that non-custodial parents should in some way be frowned upon but that non-paying non-custodial parents should be frowned on. If they have actually fulfilled their obligations without legislative requirement to do so, they should be proud of themselves and should be aware that that is honourable behaviour and should encourage it amongst non-paying non-custodial parents.

There is still anger out there. I might say that some of that anger gets to the Child Support Agency. One of the assessments I was able to participate in was in relation to the Tax Office talking about the changes required for public servants dealing with the Child Support Agency. They reported that this was not the usual area of operation for people in the tax area.

Surprisingly, what was reported was the amount of anger shown by parents raising difficulties about the Child Support Agency. I am a bit surprised about that because I would have thought that one area of the Public Service that certainly engendered anger in the community was the Tax Office. I am a bit surprised that parents only got angry when they were told they had to pay maintenance. I have never known anybody to speak kindly of a tax officer. It is interesting to note that the tax officers themselves say that the level of anger in people who are involved with child support payments was qualitatively and quantitatively different from what they had experienced before.

To pick up on a point that Senator Reid made, adequate in-service training has to be made available for people who have to deal with this amount of feeling. It is not whether the payment is $36 or $38 which enrages people; it is all those other bits of undefined areas about having to pay it, asking why they should pay it and why the new boyfriend's income is not taken into account, and so on. All of that is non-specific and very difficult to deal with but it is a matter of needing counselling skills to help people face up to this anger and deal with it constructively. There are too many examples of inappropriate behaviour as a consequence of anger. As much as possible, the Child Support Agency appreciates and recognises the areas of difficulty and deals with it.

Many of the problems are administrative. I do not need to canvass again the points that were raised by Senator Reid. There is a lot of legitimacy in all of those points that she raised. I am not in any way ascribing insufficiency to Senator Reid, as may have been understood. Those points are certainly complaints that she and others of us have received. We need to question the number and size of those complaints. The passion with which complaints in this area are raised can often make one feel it is a major problem when, in fact, it is a major problem but in small numbers. We need to have that qualifying rider in this area.

It is terribly important to stress the adequacy of training and support for staff who have to deal with people in this area, particularly when anger is still around or when anger recurs. This very often happens when the custodial spouse enters into a new relationship and that further income is not taken into account by way of, perhaps, reducing the maintenance obligations of the non-custodial parent.

We faced a difficulty in this place when we were trying to help outline the areas of design for this legislation—I note that my colleague Senator Coates is here and I certainly acknowledge his contribution to the original design of this Bill. We had to appreciate that quite often the second spouse—the new husband, let us say, in shorthand, although it need not necessarily be a second husband—may have maintenance obligations to a previous family of his own. We could not anticipate all of the possible variations and arrangements that we would have to deal with. I am quite surprised at how successful this legislation has been in terms of taking into account the complexities of the financial arrangements of people in our community.

I am also interested to see that we are now looking at those people who are asset rich and income poor and, therefore, able to avoid some of their maintenance obligations. I think it is important that we proceed gently—as this whole area of administration has proceeded—to tackle the issue of non-payment of maintenance. It is a matter of equity. It is a matter of assisting the Government to give the proper message to the community that if people have children they are charged with an obligation. It is not the nature of this Government, and certainly not the sentiment of this Government, that once people have children it does not matter that they do not care for them because they can be picked up through the social security system. It is important—and it is one of the areas where we have bipartisan support—that parents have an obligation to their children for their care and upbringing. That is one of the themes of this legislation.

When this legislation was introduced I said that the Government needed to be particularly congratulated for having the political will to implement and carry this legislation through to the stage of it becoming an Act, and setting those obligations on the community in line with the sentiments of the Government. In no way do we assist parents to abdicate their responsibilities for their children, although sometimes loose language from the Opposition suggests that we do. This legislation is exactly counter to those claims and it gives effect to a very powerfully held sentiment of the Government that we are in support of families in their business of looking after their children. This legislation provides backup support and guidance and, in this case, gives a clear outline of what we understand parents and families say are their obligations. We are not intruding between parents and children. Indeed, through this legislation we are assisting in re-establishing that contact between parent and child.

I think this Bill is consistent with the Government's intention to assist children, and aim to have no children living in poverty. Again, we could spend all night talking about the definition of `poverty'. It is also clear that we do understand that in providing sufficient money, just plain income, for families we can also assist those children to minimise poverty. As I said previously, income alone is not the only thing that is required to address moving out of poverty. We need adequate health care. We need access to education. We need parents who are confident and able to provide guidance—to shelter and lead—as their children grow to adulthood. Not all of that can be provided with income to families. In no way do we wish to undercut the income but, as well as income, other parts of this Government's policy very much address the provision of care and minimising of poverty.

It is also important to note that we do have a social security system that is in tandem with the maintenance payments, not in opposition to them and certainly not trying to replace them—not any more. That is something that the Government should stand applauded for as well. In particular, when looking at these families that are struggling to care for their children—very often with one parent and a modest income—one of the things we can note as a benefit of the establishment of this Agency is regular and consistent income. That is certainly what a lot of custodial parents have said, `At least I now know that that amount of money will be that amount and it will be provided regularly'.

I take note of what Senator Reid has said about those examples of where there have been delays. On the whole, of those parents who are now receiving payment through the Child Support Agency there is, in large part, that regular and reliable known income coming in. Most of these people are not living at the top end of the income scale. Many supporting parents and single parents with children are on modest to very meagre incomes. They have been, as defined in many places, the poorest people in our society. They are the people who struggle against the largest odds. It is important that we acknowledge the achievements of the Child Support Agency so far in addressing those questions of poverty and income maintenance and, at the same time, urging people to appreciate their responsibilities.

It is also a matter of interest for me that the Opposition, while it may support this policy here, in its Fightback package proposes to put a 15 per cent goods and services tax on all those things that people on low incomes, in particular, have to buy—food and clothing for their children. That 15 per cent tax will bite those families on low fixed or modestly increasing incomes who are least able to cope with it and for whom there will be the least amount of compensation. The Opposition's proposal of a 15 per cent tax on food and clothing for people whose income, for the large part, goes towards buying food and clothing will create terrible contrary messages to people who may see the Opposition as supporting the Child Support Agency and the legislation to assist with maintenance payments. The two run in direct conflict.

Opposition senators get up in this place and say that they care passionately about children and want to see people assisted out of poverty. They slate the Government for aiming to remove children from poverty but plan to introduce a 15 per cent tax on food and clothing for people particularly struggling at this end of the market. Opposition senators should not dare stand up and tell us about inconsistencies; they should look to their own. They are dramatic inconsistencies and they are highlighted for people who are on restricted incomes or who are enjoying maintenance through the Child Support Agency.

The amendments that have come into the Senate will assist those people who already enjoy the benefits of the Child Support Agency through the regular and reliable income it provides. They will also allow them more readily to change the terms of those agreements if and when they need to be changed. Of course, we know that from time to time we need or desire to change the agreements.

The other amendments, in terms of being able to access assets to assist in the responsibilities of maintenance, are of benefit. I also believe that the points going not so much to matters of legislation but administration under this legislation are certainly enjoying ongoing review. I believe that we may iron out the hiccups and that the legislation to this point with this further amendment certainly achieves its principal aim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also welcome the opportunity to speak on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which makes a number of changes to the existing child support legislation. Generally speaking, the Australian Democrats welcome these changes which should improve the collection of child support payments. It is clear that the support scheme is, at heart, effective; it is a sound scheme that has had good results; in other words, it has assisted with the payment of moneys that have enabled children to live a better standard of life.

PARA.TAB: In 1988, only 34 per cent of all custodial parents were receiving maintenance. By 1991, this figure had risen to 45 per cent. Indeed, for the stage 2 parents, the figure had risen to 56 per cent. Alongside this, the scheme has also brought with it a gradual change in community attitudes. I wish to quote from a recent report by a group chaired by Mr Justice Fogarty. It is entitled Child Support in Australia—Final Report of the Evaluation of the Child Support Scheme. On page 5 of Volume 1—the main report—the Advisory Group concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Scheme has challenged strongly the pre-Scheme ethos of maintenance payments being a voluntary act. The community now expects that all parents will contribute to the support of their own children and they are now more likely to make arrangements for the payment of maintenance.
For that alone it has been extremely valuable.

PARA.TAB: Before I proceed to look precisely at what is in this Bill, I want to discuss two major areas of concern. Firstly, there are continuing problems in the operation and administration of the Child Support Agency, which will undermine these positive changes unless the Government gets serious about providing adequate resources to the Agency. It is worth making this point from the outset, because it is possibly the biggest obstacle in the ongoing success of the scheme.

It is one thing for the Government to establish a collection program such as this and then to boast, quite rightly, about the amount of money that it is saving the taxpayer, but it is surely essential that the Government then properly fund the Agency concerned so that it can provide good standard, high quality service to its clients. By `clients', I mean both custodial and non-custodial parents.

I am sure that many honourable senators, or their staff, are trying to follow up on child support matters on behalf of their constituents. In doing so, they may sit for many minutes at the end of a telephone—frequently a ridiculous amount of time—waiting to get through to the Child Support Agency. Certainly for our office this seems to be one of the major continuing sources of dissatisfaction from parents and, I must add, from workers who are trying to deal with the Agency.

Recently, I met with several community based child support workers in Melbourne. They told me that their workloads have increased as more and more people have contacted them because they either could not get through to the Agency or, if they did finally get through, the resources of the Agency were such that they were not able to receive the required support and they were not able to get satisfactory advice from the Agency.

The Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group has commented that it is frequently impossible for clients to contact the Agency by telephone. Submissions received by the Advisory Group indicate that this problem is a common one, resulting in frustration and resentment towards both the Agency and the poor unfortunate staff in the scheme who are trying to deal with all this.

It seems obvious that the Agency simply does not have the resources to cope with what is an extremely high workload. Indeed, the Agency itself has admitted that its basic problem is that there are not enough staff to answer the 12,000 telephone inquiries a month. We have probably also heard complaints of errors made by the Agency and reports of unacceptable delays in written responses from it, in the registration process and the wait between the Agency's receiving maintenance payments and the forwarding of them to the custodial parent.

According to the evaluation of the scheme by the Institute of Family Studies that was published in August last year, only 55 per cent of the registered custodial parents surveyed reported receiving support payments following their entry into the scheme. The Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group reported that this delay had probably done more harm to the reputation of the scheme than any other factor. It went on to say that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . believes it is essential to the future success of the Scheme that this problem be addressed.

The Advisory Group recommended a sensible solution to the problem which would involve the Government making an advance payment to the custodial parent during this delay period and offsetting that payment against the final payment made by the liable parent. I certainly hope that the Government takes up this recommendation when the next Bill dealing with this area is before us, which I understand will be later this session.

PARA.TAB: There are already major problems with the Agency's enforcement process. The issue of enforcement is clearly linked to the confidence that people have in the scheme and their willingness to use it. The Advisory Group says that `enforcement activity by the Agency has been very disappointing', pointing out that only 57 per cent of stage 1 and 2 periodic liabilities are paid on time. It is difficult to generate confidence in the scheme when the Agency is not efficient or prompt in enforcing payment.

In situations where non-custodial parents are deliberately avoiding their obligations, the Agency needs sufficient resources to chase them up. We have had evidence that people will go to extraordinary lengths to avoid their obligations. People move frequently and change jobs. They try to hide their whereabouts and disguise their incomes. The Agency must have sufficient resources to tackle this problem. At present, it certainly does not appear to be the case that the Agency has anything like the resources it requires.

In its report, the Advisory Group points out not only that vigorous tracing is an essential prerequisite to the successful collection of maintenance liabilities, but also that unless numbers being traced are kept to a minimum, the scheme could be undermined. The Advisory Group sees a pressing need to improve the Agency's overall collection rate, which is presently running at about 65 per cent—it is some 70 per cent for stage 1 and 50 per cent for stage 2—falling well short of the Agency's own target.

Another problem is that access to the Agency is especially difficult for country people. There are few places in rural areas where people can obtain correct advice about the child support scheme. Their only option is the Agency's 008 number and there, unfortunately, the wait can be considerably longer than for a local call. Indeed, waits of up to 30 minutes are frequent. From the complaints I have had from country people about the Agency, it seems that there is a pressing need for either more community based child support workers in rural areas or for the agency to place specialist workers in the regional offices of government departments.

I do not wish with these criticisms to cast any aspersions on current Agency staff. It is quite clearly a lack of resources that is creating a major impediment to the Agency's carrying out its job properly. It is high time that the Government moved to fix the situation.

Secondly, I believe that a major problem lies with the two-tiered scheme—the fact that the scheme will be implemented in two stages. The Government has continued to refuse to extend the operation of the scheme to all children in need. Support for widening the eligibility provisions of the scheme to include all children has now come from the advisory group, the Family Law Council, the Institute of Family Studies and the vast majority of community groups and legal organisations working in this field. Indeed, Justice Fogarty, in his letter presenting the report, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990, the Advisory group advised the Government that the division of the children of Australia between Stage One and Stage Two by an arbitrary time line was unfair to the children excluded from Stage Two.

He recommended that all children have the opportunity to use stage 2. It is a matter of regret that nothing has been done by the Government on this matter. That means that a substantial number of children in Australia continue to be significantly disadvantaged and many will continue to live in poverty. The Government's continuing failure to act in this matter is a disgrace. I will be interested to hear the Minister's reasons at the conclusion of the debate tonight.

PARA.TAB: These two areas—the failure to widen the scheme and its ongoing serious administrative and operational difficulties due to lack of funds—sometimes make it difficult to get the true value of the scheme in perspective. However, it is clear that the scheme has proved cost-effective and it has certainly moved a considerable way towards ensuring non-custodial parents actually meet their obligations. Of course, it is sometimes rather difficult to get an accurate picture of the nature of the problem because the views of custodial and non-custodial parents differ so markedly. For example, the Institute of Family Studies report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Non-custodial parents were generally negative about the operation of the scheme . . . They also had a limited understanding of the collection procedures.
The report also observed:

Perhaps the most worrying polarisation between custodial and non-custodial parents occurs in their perceptions of the relationship between non-custodial parents and their children, and the effect of the Child Support Agency registration on this relationship.
This polarisation and the negative attitudes of non-custodial parents can make it rather difficult to get an accurate picture of how the scheme is working.

PARA.TAB: It is, of course, a highly emotionally charged area and allegations will continue to fly thick and fast. But we should not let highly emotive anecdotal material hide the fact that because of the child support scheme considerably more children are now being supported than was previously the case. Yes, there are problems—let us face it, there will probably always be some who have considerable difficulty facing the fact that payments must be made. I think that is due to the very traumatic nature of family breakdown. Generally speaking, I believe that most of the problems are being addressed and gradually, as they are examined, being dealt with.

The Bill certainly remedies a few outstanding problems, one of which has been that people previously had to go through the formal court process to change their assessments. The cost of this was carried by the person initiating proceedings. It could become a very costly process indeed. With this Bill, the Government is setting up an administrative review process which will enable people to have an assessment of child support reviewed by a child support review officer engaged by the Registrar. The review officer will technically be independent from the Agency and the conduct of the review will not require legal representation.

The grounds for departure from an assessment will be the same as are currently available to the court under section 117 of the Child Support Assessment Act. I know that some concerns have been expressed about section 117 and there have been suggestions that it should be widened. I believe that there is possibly a need for some extension to look at the reasonable costs of access and a number of other issues. However, I note that the Advisory Group considered that section 117 grounds had worked well, had been consistently interpreted by the courts and had maintained a satisfactory balance between the various competing interests of the custodial and non-custodial parents. The Democrats certainly support a less formal and less expensive process, but we would have preferred to have seen a tribunal process, similar to that available to social security recipients. The Democrats do not intend to move amendments at this stage to hold up in any way this legislation.

I have some concerns about the review officers. Some child-care workers have expressed to me the need for them to be seen as totally independent. The suggestion has been made that hearings should be conducted on premises other than those of the Child Support Agency. It is most unfortunate, but certainly true, that some people see the agency as being biased. The review process needs to be clearly seen to be fair and independent. I believe that one of the ways of doing this is to make sure that these reviews are held on neutral territory.

The Bill also makes a number of changes to the Registrar's capacity to recover child support debts. The Registrar will now be able to seek a court order setting aside a transaction which is intended to reduce or eliminate altogether a person's capacity to pay child support. The Registrar will also have the power to recover a child support debt from a third party, where the money is actually being held on behalf of the person who is liable for the debt, and to recover money from a liable parent who is not present in Australia. Both of these measures should enable the Registrar to act more promptly to recover child support debts.

Another provision in the Bill concerns payments made outside the Agency arrangements. At present, the Registrar can take into account payments made directly between the parties and offset them against a liability to pay the Registrar. This is a useful provision and one which is often used by parents, often in emergencies or special situations when they suddenly need some extra funds. The Bill expands the range of payments that the Registrar can take into account, including money paid to third parties. All of these moves are supported by the Australian Democrats. There are a number of other measures in this Bill which I will not go through specifically—we do not have any problems with them and we believe they will generally enhance the operation of the scheme.

As I have said, I do not believe that there is anything inherently wrong with the child support scheme. It certainly needs some finetuning. I look forward to the next piece of legislation which will deal in more detail with the report from the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group. I certainly hope that the Government does not let the report gather dust on a shelf somewhere and that it implements the suggestions.

I want to say just a word about the formula. I think it is generally acknowledged that there have been some problems with the formula, especially as it relates to second families. The Advisory Group goes into this issue in considerable detail before finally recommending an amendment to the formula along the lines suggested by Justice Kay of the Family Court. I think the Government would do well to look at Justice Kay's suggestions. I look forward to the Minister's comments later tonight on that issue.

Finally, I ask the Minister whether he will be giving consideration to the recommendation made by the Advisory Group that an independent person or body be appointed to review the performance of the scheme about 12 months after the completion of this report and advise the Minister for Social Security of the outcome. The child support scheme and the Agency charged with administering it deserve more from the Government, as do the children of Australia who are affected by this scheme. In conclusion, while supporting this Bill, I strongly urge the Government to provide the Child Support Agency with the additional resources it so urgently requires and to widen the scheme to make sure that all children are adequately dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The child support scheme was introduced in 1988 as a legislative response to a very large community problem which has not gone away. As we all know, since 1976 the divorce rate has remained at considerably high levels. Over that period, the number of divorces granted each year has fluctuated between 40,000 and 50,000, which is a great number. We have had around 700,000 divorces since the rule changed in 1976. We now have a situation where one in three first marriages ends in divorce and one in two second marriages fails as well. Of those divorces, nearly 60 per cent involve children. Since the Family Court started, a total of 750,182 children have been involved in the divorce process.

PARA.TAB: The potential for problems with such issues as custody, access, property and maintenance is enormous. History shows us that despite the ideals of the 1976 legislation, there are still many areas of dispute. Another figure of quite grave significance is that some 20 per cent of children now born in Australia are born either in de facto relationships or outside of marriage. Not surprisingly, most of the problems involve children. For a variety of reasons, non-custodial parents frequently do not pay maintenance for their children. The notion that each parent ought to be equally emotionally and financially responsible for the children is fine in theory but falls apart in the divorce process.

For a host of reasons, non-custodial parents resent paying money to ex-spouses. Notwithstanding the fact that the parents have had disagreements—this being the reason for their actual break-up—often their resentment is related to their inability to see their children as frequently as they want to. One of the reasons I first pushed for the establishment of the inquiry into the Family Law Act was that people were complaining and concerned about the fact that they could not get easy and equal access to their children. Often—and this is becoming a big issue—maintenance is not paid because a lot of those people have remarried. They have a second family and cannot afford to pay the amount of maintenance prescribed by the courts.

Against that background, however, was the increasing burden being placed on the Australian taxpayer. Increasing numbers of sole parents were turning to the taxpayer for funds with the non-custodial parent opting out of the entire process. It was obvious that something had to be done and, accordingly, the child support scheme was brought into being.

But with that scheme has come a number of problems. I note that the final report on the evaluation of the scheme also acknowledges that major difficulties are being encountered. The report refers to the intent of the scheme—that is, to ensure a collection rate as close as possible to 100 per cent. My understanding is that the Child Support Agency collects and distributes over $11m every month, but this represents only 65 per cent of the total payments made. The Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group suggests that the collection rate should and can be higher.

The report states that a number of submissions were received from non-custodial parents claiming that the formula was not fair to them—and that has been my experience in the last few years. A lot of non-custodial parents are concerned and worried that even when they have custody of their children—for example, for a weekend, a couple of days, a week or a holiday period—they still have to pay maintenance to the custodial spouse. The Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act has received numerous submissions on that very point.

Other complaints about the system include the very low level of auto-withholding or direct debit from personal accounts to the Agency; the eight-week delay between registration and first payment; and the very low level of enforcement through the courts. In other words, to date many—indeed, hundreds—of custodial parents have had little joy in pursuing what the court has determined is their actual due. As I said earlier, my electoral office is probably no different from others in terms of the number of complaints it receives about non-payment of maintenance. I am quite sure that other members of the Senate sitting here tonight would get the same complaints and the same concerns from people in the community.

The system is cumbersome, it is clumsy and I believe that it is basically flawed. In an effort to iron out these flaws, the advisory group has brought down a quite extensive report on the findings of a survey and its conclusions. I do not intend to canvass all its recommendations, but there are a couple of issues that I would like to raise. The report is pretty big and quite detailed. Some extensive work has been done in looking at the child support scheme.

The advisory group was asked to consider a before-tax versus an after-tax liability assessment. The group's decision to adhere to the before-tax formula was done on the basis that the unfairness allegation about the formula was illusory and that, even if it was applied after tax, a similar dollar result would be arrived at. But I have reservations about that and I remain to be convinced. There was considerable argument about whether a standard formula should be used, and again I remain to be convinced whether it is best to have a formula. There are problems no matter which way liability is assessed.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill does not address any of these difficulties. However, it does attempt to overcome the problem of non-payment of maintenance by suggesting that the Agency access and remove funds from banks and other places if the non-custodial parent will not pay the outstanding debts. I just do not quite know how that is going to work. In reality, basically I do not think it will work because, if one has no intention of paying, one will simply transfer one's cash reserves elsewhere. In the case of a remarried non-custodian, I would think that a transfer into the new spouse's name would overcome the ability of any government agency to access that money. Perhaps at the committee stage that will be explained by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who is at the table, and his advisers.

But one really has to question the civil liberties aspects of this move. The Opposition has moved an amendment to ensure that this becomes a last resort measure. I believe that should be the case because people do have responsibilities; and if they do not meet them, they should be chased up. But how that is to happen will have to be explained later at the committee stage.

I support the notion. But I come back to my original assertion that the issue will still be basically unresolved even after this legislation, in whatever form, finally passes this chamber. When calling for the establishment of an inquiry into family law, I was keen to include child support issues in its terms of reference. However, I do not know whether it is correct to say that I was persuaded not to do so. I was told that obviously child support is a Treasury matter, that it had nothing to do with the Attorney-General's Department and, therefore, an inquiry into the Family Law Act should pertain to that Act. In other words, matters relating to the Child Support Agency should be dealt with by way of amendments and by the inquiry that I have just mentioned. I can understand the wisdom of the people who talked me out of including the Child Support Agency in the Committee's terms of reference but I am still concerned because I do not think it is working as well as it should be.

Anyway, I deferred to wiser legal council and deleted it on the grounds that child support was not a function of the Family Law Act. But gee whiz, if it is not a part of it, it is pretty close to it because there is a very big connection between the Family Law Act, the Treasury and the Attorney-General. Given the number of submissions the Committee has received that involve child support complaints, I definitely did the wrong thing by not keeping it within the terms of reference and having it as a second part of the inquiry. We ought to have examined the issue of child support, notwithstanding this Advisory Group's existence. I still believe that it is something that the family law inquiry will have to think about solidly when we finally come to our recommendations of what does happen to the Child Support Agency.

Going back to the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group's recommendations, it has presented a lengthy two-volume report to the Parliament, but I ask other senators: where does that report go from here? Will the recommendations in that report ultimately see the light of day in legislative changes? Who will press the Government into following some of the recommendations that are being made? When Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer in this place, spoke about the increase in the amount of money, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence indicated that between 1973-74 and 1985-86 sole parents had risen from 9 per cent of the population to 15 per cent and the number reliant on social security entitlements rose from 65 per cent to 85 per cent. Social security payments in the same period rose from $160m to $1.7m, and continued to rise to $2.334m. The Government firmly believes that these statistics provided no alternative other than to introduce widespread reforms.
He said:

The ever increasing number of sole parent families, their apparent increasing poverty and the resultant growth in Government social welfare expenditure calls for a reassessment of public and private roles in providing support for families.

I have said before that the question of child support is difficult; it is costing a lot of money. Maybe we really should be thinking about why so many people are getting divorced and why so many people need child support. Maybe we should be going right back and finding out exactly what are the causes of a lot of the problems as far as marriage is concerned. Then we might not have so many problems with the Child Support Agency; we might not have so many people needing child support because people would stick together more than they have in the last little while.

PARA.TAB: As I said, there is no easy solution. To date, we have found too few answers to questions that seem to be too far away from being answered. I think we need to do more because with over three-quarters of a million children with divorced parents the problems are growing, as is the welfare budget.

This Bill is designed to introduce more flexible appeal mechanisms and collection arrangements. I hope it will achieve a little, but I doubt it. It will enhance the powers of the Registrar of Child Support to recover outstanding amounts. I have already said that I do not know whether it will achieve that. It will extend the scheme eligibility in respect of children subject to the child welfare laws. I know that Senator Alston will be speaking after the dinner break and, as Senator Reid did earlier—very succinctly, I believe—he will be putting the case for the Opposition amendments.
