TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in the debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I am grateful to my colleague Senator Reid for filling in for me at an earlier stage in the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: As the Senate will be aware—and I am sure all members and senators will be aware—this legislation, or the principal Act, has had a profound impact upon the domestic relationships of many families in Australia. By and large, most people who have been affected by it would say that, in principle, it is sound; that it was undesirable, from a community point of view—and particularly from the point of view of the children concerned—that we had a situation where something like 70 per cent of parents were not honouring their obligations. Indeed, the system did encourage people to bypass the formal requirements of maintenance and to simply approach the Department of Social Security for payment of sole parent pensions rather than expecting non-custodial parents to shoulder their portion of the responsibility.

I think the concept behind the Child Support Act has been a major step forward, and one that we would welcome. However, in recent times it has become clear that the system does not provide the flexibility that it should. Indeed, some of the structures upon which it is based are in urgent need of reconsideration.

I do not know whether others have mentioned the strict application of the formula, but on a trip I took to Mount Isa last week I was reminded in no uncertain terms of some of the extraordinary situations that can arise. For example, at the time of separation a father might be earning a modest wage—let us say, about average weekly earnings—he then separates, and has to pay, according to the formula, 27 per cent for two children. The wife is quite content with that amount; it represents a sufficient contribution, as far as she is concerned, to the welfare of the children.

He then goes to a place like Mount Isa where he finds himself working long, hard hours underground; at the same time he is earning about $60,000 or even $80,000 a year. Suddenly and automatically, there is a great windfall by way of additional payments extracted. From the representations made to me by various organisations, particularly Dads Against Discrimination (DADs), it seems clear that this really is another unintended consequence. They say to me that they can cite a number of instances where even the custodial parents have said that this is much more than they expect—in fact, more than they need—and they regard the system as inflexible in that in most instances it imposes very severe disincentives on fathers to actually get out and start a new life for themselves.

Of course, the underlying principle—that only the equivalent of unemployment benefits is set aside for the purpose of maintaining the non-custodial parent before the formula is applied—does seem to provide a massive disincentive. I think it is fair to say that we ought to have another very hard and long look at the way in which the Child Support Agency and scheme have been operating in the past few years.

This Bill is designed to introduce more flexible appeal mechanisms and collection arrangements to enhance the powers of the Registrar of Child Support to recover outstanding amounts, and it does extend some scheme flexibility in respect of children subject to child welfare laws. However, I have to say that it really only makes a very modest contribution to the sorts of reforms which seem to be very much needed.

The recent report of the Advisory Committee headed by Mr Justice Fogarty represents progress, but it does take for granted a number of these very contentious premises upon which the scheme is based and which have been a continuing source of concern to many of my colleagues. I dare say that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber would have received the same level of representations. What one finds is that whereas once immigration and welfare matters were always the bread and butter in terms of constituency representations, now it is quite common to find that child support representations outnumber the others. I know from discussions with these groups—indeed, I know from what they have told me about discussions that they have had with Senator McMullan—that there are a number of ways in which the system does bear revisiting, and some of these inflexibilities should be given further careful consideration.

At the end of the day, no-one wants to absolve people from their responsibilities. My impression of the members of DADs groups that I met, in places such as Adelaide, Perth and Mount Isa, was that they were very much committed to the concept of maintenance. They acknowledged their responsibilities. They were in no way wanting to be critical of the opposite sex. They were simply saying that the system had to be fair to all parties and that, in a number of instances, they believed that it simply imposed too great a financial burden upon one side.

One has to be as objective as possible in these matters but, certainly, a number of case studies which they put before me indicate that there are grounds for concern and one ought to be prepared to reconsider the matter. It may well be that either we need some further parliamentary scrutiny of the process or the Government itself ought to be taking the initiative—in part, I suppose, based on the reports of Mr Justice Fogarty's Committee, but also it ought to take account of many of the direct representations which a number of us have received.

As an Opposition, we support the initiatives proposed in this Bill. Modest as they are, at least they acknowledge a number of the problems that currently exist. Perhaps the major one is allowing a custodian or a liable parent to have an assessment of child support reviewed by an independent person free of charge and without legal representation by a child support review officer employed by the Registrar for that single purpose.

Although the review may be based only on grounds that are presently set out for appeals—and these are quite narrow and technical—it is nonetheless a step forward. It is just nonsense to ignore the financial consequences that flow from putting oneself in the hands of lawyers and finding that one does not get any money back. There are all sorts of incentives that take over and which quite often do not lead to the speedy resolution of matters. That can operate as a very significant deterrent for those of modest means. It only takes a few cases where people are effectively wiped out financially in the course of achieving a modest legal gain for such people to be discouraged from using the system at all. In many instances that has been part of the grievances that have been put before us.

The notion that one can vary the entitlement only if it is more than 15 per cent away from the previous year's gross income again displays inflexibility. There ought to be a much simpler method whereby people are able to establish to the satisfaction of the Registrar that their financial circumstances have changed to a lesser extent. In principle there is no reason why we should not be aspiring to accurately reflect the current financial circumstances of the parties.

This measure is there, presumably, as some sort of blunt instrument to say, `Well, we don't want to get bogged down with every minor change in financial circumstances, so we will weight it against the non-custodial party'. We do not do that to aged pensioners. We say to them, `If your financial circumstances change you have to notify the Department within 14 days'. That can be a source of great consternation to little old ladies and others, who say to me, `Will I go to gaol because I didn't tell the Department in time?'.

If we are to insist in that instance on requiring a fairly precise adjustment as soon as there is even a modest departure from the level of income disclosed, then I do not see why it needs to be at more than a 15 per cent variance before any adjustment is possible. For the purposes of example I will talk in terms of those on higher incomes and it can be seen that 15 per cent on an income of $80,000 is something of the order of $12,000. We are talking about substantial sums of money and it does not strike me as being terribly equitable to simply apply those rules of thumb. Despite the fact that it does have those limitations, allowing people to have access to an administrative review without incurring legal costs is certainly a step forward.

There are other matters contained in the legislation. In regard to the private collection of maintenance the Bill will end the mandatory requirement, but will require custodial parents to report to the Department of Social Security that payments are being made in full. Again, that is probably a reflection of the fact that there needs to be flexibility in the system. Perhaps what I should have started off with when discussing the inefficiencies in this Act is something that I am reminded of when considering this proposition, because one of the major reasons why people would prefer private collection is that they do not have to be subjected to the inordinate and inexcusable delay that quite often flows from putting oneself in the hands of the Child Support Agency.

Why it is that there needs to be delays of six to eight weeks or even longer has never been satisfactorily explained to me, other than for bureaucratic convenience. It seems to make a great deal of sense for people to work on monthly cycles and to require moneys to be paid only at a certain time and then paid out at another certain time. It is entirely supply driven and has nothing to do with the needs of the custodial parents.

In my time in this place possibly the worst example I have come across occurred some years ago when a mother complained to me that just before Christmas she had put herself at the mercy of the Agency. She had been told that there would be a delay of four or five weeks. Therefore, she approached her estranged husband and said: `Will you come to the party? Will you help the kids get some toys for Christmas?' He handed over some money. She went to the Agency and said: `There you are. It can be done. I did not have to wait for four weeks.' The Agency's immediate response was that she had acted outside the terms of the Act and must repay the money immediately. The Agency then proceeded to rebuke the father into the bargain. I find that extraordinary. I know that the Government has received many representations on this matter, but has taken no action at all. As far as I am concerned, the Government is simply sitting on that money and drawing interest on it, which benefits the Government and greatly disadvantages the non-custodial parents.

In the ultimate, there cannot be a satisfactory explanation. It is simply a matter of the Government not being prepared to advance that money on time out of its own coffers. It could be done quite simply; it is just that the bureaucrats dominate the system and will not allow that sort of flexibility to operate. It would be a very simple matter, once one has determined the entitlement of the custodial parent, to simply have the Government or the Agency pay that money out as it falls due, instead of this absolute nonsense of tying it to bureaucratic cycles and the time of payment made by the non-custodial parent. If there is one thing that needs to be tidied up urgently, it is that matter, and if my criticism can expedite the process, I will be very pleased.

Some of the other matters are really not sufficiently contentious to warrant analysis at this stage. I simply say that again they represent minor improvements only. They will not really lower the level of angst that we are all exposed to in this area. If the Government is fair dinkum about reform in this area, it will go a lot further than this Bill and will do it a lot faster than it has managed to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the fact that once again—while honourable senators have made criticisms of particular applications, detail and administrative and other arrangements—the concept underlying the child support scheme continues to have the unanimous support of both Houses of the Parliament. Boiled down to its basics, it remains a scheme the fundamental intention of which is to ensure that the resources that should properly be available from both parents are made available to support the children of those parents. It is to the credit of all involved that that basic concept remains one that has the support of all in the Parliament, notwithstanding that every time we deal with a constituency matter in this regard, or a concern raised by people, we are venturing into a very volatile field.

PARA.TAB: I know from experience in my other areas of responsibility that when one deals with people's financial and tax arrangements one is dealing with a very sensitive area. We all know from our other experiences in dealing with matters of family law that it is an extremely sensitive area. When the two are put together, each problem is of great sensitivity and is beyond what would be a mere tax or a mere family law problem, because the two come together and reinforce each other as concerns to the citizens involved. That is perfectly reasonable and understandable and it is a matter that requires continuing sensitivity by members on all sides of this House and in the House of Representatives. Although I receive many representations from people, in the main they are within those parameters. They are people who are expressing concern on behalf of their constituents, but who are continuing to support the fundamentals of the scheme. I welcome that.

As other speakers have said, the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill makes a number of changes to the original child support legislation. It has a number of features, but I will refer to only a few, and principally the introduction of the administrative review process and the enhancement of the powers of the Registrar to recover amounts that are due. Those are the two key elements. In summing up, I will not recount all those elements that were outlined in the second reading and which are otherwise outlined in the Bill. They are designed to enhance what the scheme has already achieved. It has achieved a significant turnaround in outcomes for children. It has achieved a significant improvement in the amount of income flowing to children—many of whom would otherwise be in great need—from the non-custodial parent. This has been achieved not at the expense of the taxpayers, but properly at the expense of the parent who should be paying.

It has also engendered the beginning of a change in attitudes. There is an increasingly widespread acceptance of the appropriateness of the approach that parents should contribute to the upkeep of their children, whether they are together or separate. I welcome the fact that, as Senator Alston said—and it has also been my experience—the organisation which goes under the acronym DADs has made it clear when speaking to me that it is prepared to support only the people who recognise the basic premise that they have a responsibility to support their children. The organisation then argues about the detail and sometimes I disagree, but I welcome the fact that it operates from that principle. That is a principled position to take. I appreciate that it is much harder for that group to be objective about this than it is for me, and I welcome the fact that it is able to deal with it in that principled manner.

Let me respond to the first point made by Senator Alston before I go back through the comments made by other honourable senators as briefly as possible. I do not agree with his windfall example, because the principle is that the children's position in relation to the income of the parents should be substantially that which it would have been had there not been a separation. Had the parents been together and the father—as it is in this case—gone to Mount Isa and received a substantially enhanced income, the benefit—

TALK.START.PARA: —He only goes to Mount Isa because the marriage has broken up.
—Nevertheless, the benefits of that extra income should be available to the children in exactly the same manner as they would otherwise be.
—But the cost of maintaining those children hasn't risen.

—What we and other Australians contribute to our children is proportionate to our capacity to contribute. Those with higher incomes contribute more. That is why this is a percentage based scheme; it is why it should be a percentage based scheme; and it is why it will continue, for as long as we are involved, to be a percentage based scheme, including percentage of extra income earned. I understand that it is a source of anxiety for people, but I think that that is the correct principle and I intend, certainly for as long as I am involved, to support its continuation.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lot of emphasis on the inflexibility of the formula. There is one thing I want to say about that. By its very nature, a formula to have an administrative based resolution rather than requiring people to go to court, or resolving matters in the old ways, is a fixed arrangement in relation to a number of variables that are put into that fixed formula, and it produces an outcome. It is quite clear that the Government recognises, and has recognised since the inception of the scheme, that that can cause unfairness. Therefore, there are a number of mechanisms by which that can be varied—by private agreement and by the court. There will now be the capacity for it to be varied to take account of the special circumstances of the case by the new review officers. That is one of the advantages of the introduction of the new review officers.

We do not want a scheme that would apply hundreds of qualifications, make it exceedingly complex and probably do away with it as a formula based scheme; we would get back to case by case assessment of the merits without a need to review the formula. There are many cases—none of us hear about them because they are not the ones that people bring to our offices—where the formula applies satisfactorily, the money flows, children are better off and the level of anxiety between the parents is lower than it otherwise might have been. They are the ones that we do not hear about and they are helping thousands of children around Australia.Senator Reid raised that point as well as others. She went on to raise a number of matters. In the time that I want to take tonight I will not deal with all of them, but I will try to deal with the major ones.

She raised the obvious question about the powers of the review officers. The Act is intended to establish that their powers in relation to an assessment will be the same as those of a court. In other words, if a review officer makes a decision, that will vary the formula in that case and the assessment will operate on the basis of the decision of the review officer. It would not obviate the right of an individual to go to court. The court case would not be an appeal against the review officer's decision. It would be—I think in the jargon that Senator Reid would know better than I—a de novo hearing. It would be as if the review process had not taken place. Obviously, it would only be triggered by dissatisfaction with the review officer's decision, although that would not be the formality of the matter before the court. We would hope that there would not be many of those. That is why the review officers are being introduced. Time will tell, but that is our hope and I think it is a reasonable expectation. I would think that this process would be more capable of resolving the sorts of matters that I see often.

Senator Reid raised—and it was raised in the House of Representatives and has been raised with me by my colleagues—the administrative problems with the Child Support Agency. I am not going to pretend that they do not exist. They are primarily a product of the enormous volume of cases. Initially, there was a massive one-off surge and it was thought that the number of cases coming would slow dramatically. We now have to face the reality that it appears unlikely that it will ever slow in the manner originally envisaged. We are having to consider that and some of the administrative structures, and we are doing that in the light of the Fogarty recommendations. They are very helpful. We have not made our decision about them. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and I will be consulting with our colleagues in the Social Security and Attorney-General's portfolios to make final decisions on that.

There is always difficulty in the area of enforcement procedures. People have an expectation that, because it is the Government taking the enforcement action on their behalf, we have the capacity to act in a manner that other people before courts do not. Of course, we have to go through the same process of getting orders, giving people time to appeal and all of those things that sometimes make court proceedings so lengthy.

I did not hear this particular point, although I was trying to listen from my office to what Senator Reid said. I understand that she raised, and certainly others have raised, the concern that priority may be given to the largest cases. I have sought and received assurances that that is not the process. Priority is to be set by the date of the case, with one qualification, which I think is a sensible one and which I will mention in a moment. In essence, that is the priority setting, not the amount outstanding, which would be the more normal Australian Taxation Office procedure, and people can understand why that would be the case.

The qualification is that there is some current thinking that if priority can be given to the small, very recently instituted bills it might lead to a situation where they do not escalate and those cases can more quickly and readily be brought into line. Therefore, the bigger enforcement charges will not arise. That is a new administrative arrangement that is being pursued. I think it is sensible, but it will have to be judged after some development of it. It is hoped that the new and enhanced powers of the Registrar to garnishee, as established by this Bill, will assist in the enforcement process.

Everybody expresses concern about the stress and pressure that is put on the staff of the Child Support Agency. That is true. They, individually, work remarkably well. I have been to all the Agency offices. I have met many of the staff. I have great admiration for them. That is not to say that they do not get things wrong because they do—they are humans dealing with hundreds and thousands of difficult cases—but they work very well and I give them my support. That does not mean we do not want to review the way that they work. I certainly do and we will use the Fogarty Report to look at some of the issues that have been raised. I support the individuals. I know that many members of the House of Representatives and the Senate have experienced great assistance from them as well as difficulties in some cases.

I have to say that the hard working staff would not be enhanced if we found policies being espoused which suggest that the efficiency dividend should be increased and the number of public servants being employed by governments should be cut. That is not the way to assist those staff or to assist the administration of this Child Support Agency. I think that would be a most unfortunate factor. We have to bear in mind, when people raise the issue, that perhaps there should be more staff. The last thing we need is the introduction of rigid increases in efficiency dividends that would, in fact, reduce the staff available to the Child Support Agency.

Senator Lees raised two issues, both of which flow from the reviews. One is the question of widening the scheme to allow the formula to apply in all cases. The second is Justice Kay's proposal about second families. All I can say is that they are both under consideration. They are part of the considerations flowing from the Fogarty Report and the Government will be making a decision and an announcement about that.

Senator Brownhill raised the continuing issue of whether this assessment should be based on before tax or after tax income. There are two fundamental issues to be addressed. The first is that whichever measure is used, it is the amount of money that is being targeted not the percentage. If we change to an after tax formula, we would have to increase the percentages to provide the level of income as assessed initially by the committee that developed the child support scheme and there would be no benefit to the non-custodial parent.

While I understand the concerns they raised, we should point that out to them and the fact that it would increase the administrative complexity of the arrangement because, while taxable income is readily available, after-tax income would be a new calculation that would need to be made over and above those that are readily available. There is concern about how the garnishee scheme will work. Put simply in the time available, these powers already exist under the tax Act and they will operate here in the same way as they operate there. I will come back to deal with some elements of that in the committee stage. As I said, we are proposing here the same powers that apply in the tax Act.

There are a number of other issues I could raise but I think that goes to the main questions raised by honourable senators in the debate. We all want to get the legislation passed as quickly as possible and get on to the subsequent and important sales tax legislation that also has to come before us tonight. I thank honourable senators for their support and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 18, page 11, after proposed subsection 72A(1), insert the following subsection:

"`(1A) The Registrar must not give written notice to a person in accordance with subsection (1) unless the appeal and review rights of the person in relation to child support debts in accordance with this Act have been exhausted.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is designed to ensure that, before the Registrar exercises what are, on the face of it, very wide powers to give third parties notice to pay across to the Agency moneys that might have been owed to a non-custodial parent who has declined to honour his or her obligations to the custodial parent, the Registrar must ensure that all the appeal and review rights of the non-custodial parent have been exhausted. In other words, it is not good enough simply to assume that those rights probably have been exhausted or to be indifferent about whether the time for appeal has expired. The onus will be on the Registrar not to take action unless and until all those processes have been gone through. Therefore, we are anxious to ensure that people's rights are protected at all times.

PARA.TAB: It is highly desirable that one execute only on debts that have been fully proven. The last thing one really wants is for moneys to be garnisheed and handed over, then to discover that it was not a fully proven debt. The amendment is designed simply to tighten up the requirements to that extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the appropriate course is for me to deal with Senator Alston's amendment first and then to move mine subsequently. I appreciate the succinct manner in which Senator Alston moved his amendment and I will try to be equally brief in response.

PARA.TAB: The principal issue from the Government's point of view is that the power here is identical to the power contained in section 218 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There is nothing new or novel about it. It will be exercised only within guidelines, as is the case with the sections under the Income Tax Assessment Act, and we do not need, and should not be making, special arrangements here. The guidelines are currently being drawn up and they will be followed in the exercise of this power. Given that the guidelines are not at this stage available, I understand that the Committee would want to be assured that they will be guidelines with which it is happy. I make it clear this evening, and will confirm tomorrow, that when those guidelines first become available I will make a copy available to Senator Alston and Senator Lees so that they can comment about the adequacy or otherwise of them.

While I do not want to see this legislative restriction, for reasons I will comment on briefly in a moment, over and above saying that I do not see why we need a greater restriction in pursuing child support debt than tax debt because it may slow the flow of the money to the children, which is the intention of the scheme, I accept that the corollary of that is that the guidelines under which they operate must be satisfactory guidelines. I am quite happy to make those available to the representatives of the parties in the area concerned, who will make them effectively available to any honourable senator who wishes to obtain a copy. The problem is that the proposed amendment can delay the flow of money to the custodians for the benefit of the children.

While in many instances it is clear that appeal processes need to be protected—and that is certainly right; no-one wants to interfere with the question of due process—to put it succinctly and without unduly taking the time of the Committee because, as I say, Senator Alston was succinct, the experience of the operation of a similar section under the Income Tax Assessment Act indicates that we do not need to provide greater protection here than we do there where the flow of money is not just the Government pursuing a debt to it but the Government, in this instance, pursuing a debt on behalf of the children of the non-custodial parent. I do not think we should be less diligent and empower the Taxation Office less, in this instance through the Child Support Registrar, to pursue these debts than we are in pursuing the normal tax debts to the Commonwealth.

We will, through the guidelines, preserve the rights of individual men and women affected. To reassure people about the adequacy of the guidelines, I am happy to make them available for scrutiny by honourable senators and other interested people, but the key for the purpose of this debate is by honourable senators. I do not want to create a situation where we could, for example, pursue a debt by way of PAYE deduction from Australian wage and salary earners but cannot in the same circumstances pursue the same debt under the garnishee provisions because we are restricted by this amendment. It is substantially the same debt but because the employment circumstance of the individual is different the capacity to act is different.

I do not think it is fair, although I understand that its motivation is to protect the rights of citizens. We ought to protect them otherwise and try to expedite the flow of the money to the children as far as is possible within the guidelines I have referred to. So for that reason we do not support the amendment, although if I understand Senator Alston correctly, and what he said seems to confirm it, I understand the motivation but I do not like the process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also have great problems with this amendment. The people Senator Alston is concerned about are often the ones that are hardest to pin down—the debtors who are the hardest to make come up with the money. I believe this amendment would mean that they could postpone indefinitely their responsibilities—postpone the garnishee action indefinitely. The Australian Democrats do not believe that this is either desirable or appropriate.

PARA.TAB: The power the Government is giving in this legislation is there to save time and avoid the necessity of having to obtain an order from the court against the third person who is holding money for the child support debtor. I ask Senator Alston why these debtors should be provided with an extra opportunity to avoid their responsibilities when, as has already been stated, regular wage and salary earners are already liable to be garnisheed for outstanding amounts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wage and salary earners are owed money by their employers for having rendered services. It is almost impossible to conceive a situation in which one could ultimately argue that the money was not owed to you because you had not done the work. It would have to be said that somehow he was on the job but doing his work so badly that he did not deserve to be paid. So the establishment of a debt is a very clear and simple matter.

PARA.TAB: It is not so simple when moneys are claimed back from third parties. They may or may not be held on trust for the debtor. They may or may not be owed for a valid reason. It may relate to the sale or purchase of a motor vehicle. Money may simply be paid to someone who is a relative, but it may have nothing to do with the actual debtor. Therefore, all we want to do is to give the debtors their right in law, which is no more or less than the opportunity to ensure that the legal rights they have are able to be pursued and that the Registrar does not act prematurely.

I accept what Senator McMullan says. I hope that in almost every instance we will not have any problems of the Registrar firing first and asking questions later or taking action and then discovering that injunction proceedings and the like are being launched. I presume such action could still be taken. It is really just wanting to slow him down, to ensure that he is satisfied that there is no argument about the debt. That does not involve stringing people along or letting them go beyond the strict limits of the law. It does impose an obligation on the Registrar in a formal way to ensure that the money is properly owing.

Senator McMullan is saying that he will regard himself as subject to that and he will act accordingly. In view of the views of the Senate, we will not pursue this matter to division but will obviously be anxious to ensure that it operates as it should.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian automotive industry, particularly the luxury vehicle portion, must wonder what it has done to deserve what the Government has been handing out to it in recent years. The constant changing of the wholesale sales tax laws, combined with the Government's induced recession, has proved so detrimental to the automotive industry, one wonders whether it will ever get a chance to recover.

PARA.TAB: I probably do not need to remind my fellow senators of the copious tax laws and tax flaws which have been through this place since 1990. The whole mess began when Mr Keating, the then Treasurer, announced that the rate of sales tax payable on motor cars and station wagons, including four-wheel drive vehicles, with a wholesale value exceeding $28,793 was to increase from 30 per cent to 50 per cent. While the initial announcement created a surge in sales, the end result was a negative impact on government revenue. This was quite a rude shock for the Government, despite the Opposition's warning it that this would happen. As a result, the sales tax requirements were changed.

The Government's second attempt at altering the sales tax on luxury cars was to amend the tax system so that it commenced at 30 per cent for vehicles priced at $30,234 and increased to a maximum of 50 per cent for vehicles with a wholesale price equal to or greater than $54,419. Subsequently, some 12 months later, the Government decided to review the higher rate luxury tax and reverted to the pre-May 1990 arrangements; that is, 30 per cent. In announcing the reversion to the previous regime, the Government conceded that since the introduction of the higher rate of luxury sales tax in May 1990, there had been a dramatic contraction in sales in that sector. Monthly sales are now running at less than a third of the level of the years before the tax changes.

The Government's change of policy was too late; the serious consequences had already been felt by vehicle manufacturers and importers. In much the same way, the sales tax changes proposed today are too late. The thousands of Nissan workers and their families will tell us that. We never heard from the Government what the actual revenue figures for wholesale sales tax collected from luxury cars were during this period of confused wholesale sales tax rulings.

The Sales Tax Amendment Bill before us today is primarily about reducing the wholesale sales tax from 20 per cent to 15 per cent for passenger vehicles that have a wholesale sale value of $30,505 or less. A secondary, but perhaps more important, issue that arises from this Bill is the impact of clause 4, which amends the second schedule by omitting the current wordy definition of `sales tax rate' and substituting `"sales tax rate" means 0.2 per cent'. This apparently simple definitional change has altered the formula used for calculating the luxury car tax threshold. The formula concerned has as one of its components, defined by the letter `C', the sales tax rate which applies to vehicles not affected by the 30 per cent sales tax limit. This was 20 per cent, or 0.2.

If the Government had stuck with its original definition of the component, from 27 February 1991 the component should have been reduced to 15 per cent, or 0.15. However, the definitional change means that the component stays at 20 per cent, or 0.2. Therefore, under this legislation the sales tax retail threshold and the depreciation limit are no longer the same. For years the industry had been pushing for this nexus to be broken. The Government held out and said, `No, it is desirable to have a nexus'. But when it saw a revenue implication it chose to break it. It has chosen to break it in unfortunate circumstances which have given rise to a great deal of confusion in the industry.

We believe it is necessary to correct this situation by an amendment, which we will move in the committee stage. The Government's Bill creates an unnecessary anomaly in that it results in a retail price threshold for sales tax purposes of $43,936.76, yet retains the income tax depreciation limit of $45,462. The amendment that will be introduced by my colleague Senator Short seeks to overcome this problem by ensuring that the retail threshold price at which the tax rate increase is triggered would remain tied to the income tax depreciation limit. In achieving this, the amendment does no more than reinstate the policy adopted by the Government when it introduced the highly discriminatory luxury car tax in 1986. The Government is now proposing to abandon this policy without any sound reason or explanation, to the confusion and detriment of the industry.

Logic dictates that the luxury car tax threshold should not fall below the income tax depreciation limit. To do otherwise would mean, in practical terms, a reduction by stealth in the income tax depreciation limit as it now applies to new motor vehicles. I believe that this is just not good enough. It is poor legislation, it is poor drafting, and it is done by stealth. We have a great deal of confusion as a result of this proposal.

I also remind the Senate that there is a substantial sales tax penalty under the Government's Bill. Because of an increase in the retail price of a new vehicle from $43,935 to $45,462 no new vehicles could be priced in this range. A $1 retail price increase above the $43,936 threshold would bring about a doubling in the quantum of sales tax payable from $4,575.72 to $9,151.44. That is the implication of this apparently simple change to the sales tax legislation. I believe that the Senate should endorse an amendment to be moved by my colleague which seeks to align the depreciation level and the threshold.

In practical terms, the depreciation limit for new vehicles will fall from $45,462 to $43,936.76 under the Government's Bill. Yet this has not been publicly announced by the Government. It is a little dishonest. Under previous wholesale sales tax legislation covering luxury vehicles, a retail price void existed between $45,462 and $48,512. The interesting point about this is that within this range it was mathematically impossible to calculate the correct quantum of sales tax payable. The Tax Office had to come to the party, so it resolved this problem outside the Parliament by ruling that vehicles priced in this void should be taxed at the rate of 30 per cent applied to the wholesale sales tax threshold of $30,504.81.

As a result of this Bill, the retail void will extend to the range from $43,937 to $48,512. We have this completely unacceptable mathematical situation which is adverse to the industry. The implication of this is that the distributors of vehicles in this price range will be denied the opportunity of reintroducing to their vehicles vital and effective safety measures such as anti-lock braking systems.

The other problem which this aspect of the Bill raises is with regard to the relevance of the depreciation limit as set down in section 57AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I remind the Senate that when the Treasurer announced $18,000 as the 1979 base limit for depreciation, in those days it was possible to buy the most expensive Australian-produced motor vehicle for less than that amount. I think the yardstick adopted was the Ford LTD or thereabouts. In 1992 a Ford LTD is priced in the $52,000 range, well above the section 57AF limit of $45,462. There are other glaring inequities in the application of section 57AF which relate primarily to the calculation of the relevant consumer price index by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

When section 57AF was enacted it may well have been the case that $18,000 was not an unreasonable threshold. However, there was a substantial bias in the methodology adopted by the CPI section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics in Canberra over the last decade. In effect, the average level of change in the motor vehicles purchase sub-group of the CPI is calculated by reference to what could be described only as a fictional vehicle. It appears that acceptable standards and features that are found today in what could fairly be described as an average family car are removed effectively to return the vehicles to 1979 standards. For example, where a manufacturer was offering as optional equipment an item or items which are now provided as standard—such as air-conditioning or power steering—the value of those sorts of items is discounted. Not only does such a methodology make a nonsense of section 57AF of the Income Tax Act but it also has the effect of substantially undervaluing the limit in 1992 dollars.

The problems are then translated into the sales tax legislation by virtue of the adoption of the section 57AF limit for luxury car tax threshold purposes. Obviously the Government has made the calculation change in full consciousness of the end result. Why else would it be stated so succinctly in the Bill? However, it does nothing to improve the image of the wholesale sales tax as anything other than an inefficient, inequitable and administratively complex tax.

I remind the Senate that if the coalition's Fightback GST proposal were in place, the sorts of difficulties that the industry is now facing and the problems that we are now grappling with in the Senate would not arise. The Government is presenting to the Senate formulae for calculations that are unintelligible to the ordinary lay person. That a fair wholesale sales tax cannot be calculated on a range of prices just indicates the inadequacies of the wholesale sales tax regime in modern day Australia. When it was introduced, it was probably a quite fair and not unreasonable tax, but now it does not meet the needs of an efficient economy taking its place in world affairs and having to compete internationally.

With regard to clause 6 and passenger motor vehicles, which are covered by Customs Tariff Act heading 8703, it is interesting to note what is not included under this heading. The vehicles which will not be considered as passenger motor vehicles for the purpose of this Bill and therefore not have their wholesale sales tax reduced to 15 per cent include panel vans, delivery vans, utilities, dual cabins, jeeps, trucks, off-road four-wheel vehicles, lorries and motor buses.

What benefit will this reduction really have for business communities? This definition seems to exclude any vehicle which could typically be used by a business. The point that I am making is that, apart from the motor vehicle sales industry, there is no relief for business in the initiative put forward. The Government is trying to get as close to the 15 per cent GST rate as it possibly can.

As a bit of an aside, I want to comment on clause 6 of the Bill, which amends the fifth schedule. In changing the words of this schedule, it would appear that the Government is admitting that, despite its wholesale sales tax cut of 5 per cent, the Australian motor vehicle manufacturing industry is dead. What other explanation could there be for changing the classification of cars according to the import of products classification 8703?
In his second reading speech, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Sales of passenger motor vehicles have suffered heavily in the economic downturn. This has had adverse employment effects throughout the economy for domestic manufacturers, retailers and importers. The reduction in the rate of sales tax for passenger motor vehicles, other than luxury vehicles, will help to stimulate demand for these vehicles.

One is then left to conclude—though it was not stated—that this stimulated demand for vehicles will stimulate the economy and, hey presto, Mr Keating is able to justify his pump-priming measures announced last week.

PARA.TAB: If this is the Government's plan, I wonder what its reaction is to the announcement this week by General-Motors Holden and Toyota that they will be lifting the price of a number of popular family vehicles from anywhere between one and 3.5 per cent. The net effect of this rise will be to wipe out the tax saving which the Government was intending to lure consumers with to increase car purchases and thus help the economy. According to Toyota, the price rises are due to the fall in the value of the Australian dollar before Christmas. They are expected to take effect in the second quarter—that is, from April until June. At least in introducing this Bill the Government is acknowledging that its wholesale sales tax does have an impact on the purchasing decision of consumers and thus is a stimulus to the economy.

I now invite the Government to look at the implications of a GST. What a pity the Government does not have the courage to bite the bullet, scrap the wholesale sales tax completely and replace it with the goods and services tax proposed by the coalition. Slowly but surely in this place we are seeing wholesale sales tax changes which are consistent with what the coalition has been proposing in its Fightback package. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 was a good example of this. The sales tax Bill now before us alters the wholesale sales tax on non-luxury vehicles from 20 to 15 per cent, the same as would apply under a GST. However, a direct comparison cannot be made because, for example, car accessories, including tyres, still attract a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax. Of course, those in business get no relief by way of a credit for their input taxes.

This Bill is only one of many sales tax Bills that, under this Government, we seem to pass inevitably each year in a vain effort to patch up the wholesale sales tax system. But we are making it more complicated, unintelligible, inequitable and mathematically difficult to calculate accurately the correct sales price of the item in question. I therefore foreshadow that, in the committee stage of this Bill, my colleague Senator Short will be putting an amendment that we have negotiated with the Government. That will occur tomorrow afternoon.

We wish to add at this stage that the Government has increased the amount of revenue raised through sales tax from $3.5 billion in 1982 to $9.4 billion last year. This figure would have been much higher had it not been for the recession, which has served to depress sales. Sales tax collections are down to something like 7.6 per cent.

The impact of the Government's sales tax grab on households, as on others, has been particularly severe. Unfortunately, the sales tax rates are levied on a narrow range of goods which discriminate very nastily and cause massive problems in the economy. The sooner we ensure this change the better, because in the process the rates and the quantum have become very regressive and have affected a number of items quite detrimentally.

I therefore conclude by urging the Government to examine the problems that it has created, note the matters that have been raised in my speech and at least ensure that it removes this unnecessary anomaly that results in the retail price threshold for sales tax purposes being substantially different from the income tax depreciation limit. We maintain that the two should be in equilibrium and in conformity with the policy announced prior to this Bill. It can be done, and the Opposition amendment will show how it can be done, although unfortunately it is a fairly complicated formula to arrive at an equitable result.

One recent tax decision that should be brought into the public debate is the decision in the State Bank case. It probably has very severe ramifications for the proposed goods and services tax. TALK.START.PARA: —Some of my colleagues on this side of the chamber—Senator Watson, Senator Panizza and others—have very eloquently outlined tonight the views of the coalition in relation to many of the aspects of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.1) 1992. PARA.TAB: The Bill which we are debating implements the Government's decision to reduce the wholesale sales tax on some passenger motor vehicles from 20 per cent to 15 per cent. It is part of the package of hastily cobbled together measures announced by the Government on 26 February as part of its so-called One Nation—but in reality one job, namely, Paul Keating's job—plan to buy its way through to the next election.

As I said, the Bill is nothing other than a political stunt. In fact, we are now informed via the media, which again reflects the Government's penchant for government by press release rather than by being open and honest in this Parliament, that the Government has agreed to remove the luxury tax car threshold, having reduced it to $43,937 in what, quite frankly, has been an awful mix-up in the sales tax area.

As long ago as 12 March in the Australian, the relevant Minister, Senator Button, is reported to have said that the Government recognised the problem that has been seen by everyone other than the Government in relation to the proposals contained in the economic statement of 26 February and that the Government was looking at making the necessary changes. The Government is consumed with trying to make a political gain whilst overlooking the burdens and costs that it has created for the rest of the community.

What can we expect now so far as the Government is concerned? Given the statement reported in the press by Senator Button on 12 March, is there to be another amendment moved by the Government? What more changes will there be to wholesale sales taxes generally, the categories of vehicles, the price at which a car is deemed to become a luxury car or the depreciation limit? What can we and, more importantly, the industry expect next? It is precisely this sort of confusion and indecision by government that is very importantly a cause of the major crises that we have in Australian industry today and the lack of confidence on the part of industry in terms of its investment and development processes generally.

When are the foreshadowed changes which were announced by the Minister on 12 March via a press release going to be made? If they are going to be made soon, why have they not been introduced tonight? It is clear that, in opting for a 15 per cent wholesale sales tax rate, the Government somehow thinks it can counter the appeal of the coalition's proposed goods and services tax and the beneficial price effects that will flow on to consumers and the industry from the coalition's tax reforms. I talk about those tax reforms in the broadest sense which, of course, include the abolition of the fuel excise which will reduce the costs to industry of fuel by no less than 25c a litre and a private motorist by 19c a litre and which will have an enormous impact on the cost of the transport industry in Australia. The cut in wholesale sales tax from 20 to 25 per cent applies only to some vehicles. It is obviously not designed for efficiency, simplicity or fairness—which are the three essences of a proper and equitable tax system; rather, it is designed to have the best political impact for the Government.

This Government does not seem to be able to help itself when it comes to putting political gain ahead of economic efficiency or the overall interests of Australians as a whole. The reduction in sales tax does not apply to so-called luxury vehicles, which will continue to be taxed at the so-called luxury rate of 30 per cent. Let me make it clear that in saying that, the coalition is not suggesting that it do otherwise, but it is a point that ought to be noted.

Nor does the reduction from 20 per cent to 15 per cent apply to off-road vehicles such as four-wheel drives. Trucks, delivery vans, motor cycles, ambulances and a range of other vehicles will also continue to be taxed at the higher rate of 20 per cent. As a result, farmers, small business people and a range of other business users—the essence of job creation and income and wealth creation in this country—will largely miss this reduction.

The reduction will apply only to eligible vehicles with a wholesale value of $30,505 or less. The Bill—and this is one of my main criticisms of it—adds to the complexity and, therefore, to the administrative and compliance costs of the already cumbersome and anomaly-driven and anomaly-ridden wholesale sales tax system. No less than five rates of sales tax will apply to vehicles: some will be taxed at nought per cent; some at 10 per cent; some at 15 per cent; some at 20 per cent; and some at 30 per cent.

Where does that sit with the promise of the Government back in the beginning of 1990, I think, to simplify the wholesale sales tax system? I would hope that when the Minister sums up in this debate tonight or during the committee stage tomorrow, on behalf of the Government he will tell us just where the simplification of the wholesale sales tax process is at the moment. Certainly nothing seems to have happened since the announcement in February 1990 that that tax simplification process was to be put in train; nothing has been heard of it since. It is about time that the Government announced its intentions and its timetable in relation to that simplification process, if indeed there is any continuing simplification or timetable involved.

The answer to all of this is that the coalition's package of tax reforms is the only way to go, and the Government knows that. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was the most articulate advocate back in 1985 of the very route of tax reform that the coalition is now proposing. He said then that the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and its replacement with a goods and services tax of a uniform rate was the only way to go if we were to get the tax system of this country into line with the twentieth century.

We have the most archaic, anomaly-ridden, inefficient tax system in the whole world. The Government knows that; the coalition knows that. The coalition at least has the courage and the foresight to put specific suggestions to the Australian people for tax reform. The Government has backed away from that at every stage and it has backed away from that at every stage since its master, the ACTU in the form of Bill Kelty, back in 1985 said to the Government during the famous tax summit which was going to change all these things, `We will not buy a broadly based consumption tax.'

At the end of day one of the famous tax summit in 1985, the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, pulled the rug on the whole tax reform process. SPEECH.PARA: The Ministers preparing the statement agreed the political risks associated with being seen as responding to the Coalition's economic program outweighed any benefits in clearing up a tax system that the Government concedes privately is in a mess.

PARA.TAB: That is the essential difference between the approaches of the Government on the one hand and the coalition on the other in relation to the two packages that we have put to the Australian people for the next election. Why did the Government not bite the bullet and abolish payroll tax in the way that the coalition has proposed? Quite honestly, but privately, the Government admits that needs to be done. A major anomaly created by this Bill is that it separates the luxury car tax threshold from the depreciation limit. Between 1986 and 1992, those two prices have been the same.

The depreciation limit is set, albeit arbitrarily, at $45,462 under section 57AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Under Item 61 of the Second Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, there is a formula designed to ensure that only those vehicles with a retail price above the depreciation limit are subject to the so-called luxury sales tax rate of 30 per cent. That linkage was achieved by taking the depreciation limit of $45,462 retail and deeming that the wholesale price of such a vehicle was $31,564. That is, if a wholesale price of $31,564 is assumed and a wholesale sales tax of 20 per cent is applied, plus the normal dealer margin, one would arrive at a retail price of $45,462. What a bureaucratic device and bureaucrat's delight that sort of approach is! The net result is that it has created a very significant anomaly in the practical situation affecting the vehicle market.

Vehicles with a wholesale price above $31,564 were classified as luxury vehicles and were subject to a tax of 30 per cent. If the wholesale price of a car was one dollar over that limit, the entire value was taxed at 30 per cent. That, of course, had the effect of driving the retail price of such a car to $48,512. Hence, in all of that, there was a pricing void. A black hole existed between the maximum retail price under the 20 per cent tax—that retail price being $45,462—and the minimum retail price under a 30 per cent tax, namely, $48,512.

Under this Bill, the deemed maximum wholesale price to which the new 15 per cent tax applies will be $30,505. That will be the point at which the tax switches from 15 per cent to 30 per cent. Under the formula, a wholesale price of $30,505 and a tax of 15 per cent translates to a retail price of $43,937 as distinct from the figure of $45,462. So we have the situation where the luxury car retail price threshold is reduced to $43,937 but the depreciation limit for the same vehicle remains at $45,462. I am sure that is absolutely confusing to those who are listening to this debate or who will read the Hansard of it. It is certainly confusing enough for the industry and the sooner the Minister comes up with the necessary changes, which he conceded two or three weeks ago through the media, the better.

I see Senator McMullan here, and I hope that in summing up this debate, and particularly when we move into the committee stage, he will advise us of what the Government is proposing to do to unravel the enormous confusion, uncertainty and, consequently, lack of confidence this situation has provoked.

A further adverse effect of the change is that it increases the size of the pricing void or black hole that I referred to earlier. That void now extends from $43,937 to $48,512. It becomes impossible to price a car in that range because of the large amount of extra tax to be paid once the retail price of $43,937 is exceeded. Although the legislated depreciation limit remains at $45,462, this black hole effect means that cars will not be priced at that level. Instead, the retail threshold of $43,937 will become the de facto depreciation limit. This represents a lowering of the depreciation limit by absolute stealth.

The price distortions which flow from this complex and unnecessary interference in the market are bad for the industry and very bad indeed for consumers. At face value, the price reductions may be welcomed by those consumers who purchase the particular range of vehicles affected, but there are also very large costs involved. One of those is the underhand protection being granted to local manufacturers whose products fall mainly in the price range under the luxury threshold. Another is the incentive which this price distortion creates to remove safety equipment such as air bags and ABS anti-lock braking in order to reduce the wholesale price below that 30 per cent tax threshold level. Any tax or intervention which openly discourages the inclusion of safety equipment should not be tolerated by this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to take up a problem that has been a source of confusion for tax workers, advisers and researchers and a thorn in the side of tax publishers for almost 40 years. I believe there is a solution to the problem and that the solution is in the hands of the Government via the Australian Taxation Office. The problem we have before us lies in the identification for publishing and reference purposes of decisions of the Taxation Appeals Division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on reviews of taxation objection decisions. Decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, Taxation Appeals Division, are reported under two quite different systems of identification by Butterworths and CCH, though it is the same case. For example, AAT case 6179, 1990, 21 ATR 3645 from Butterworths is reported as case X74 90 ATC 555 by CCH. That is, of course, the same case.

PARA.TAB: The problem can be explained as follows. The publication of the AAT decisions under two separate and independent identifiers is a source of unnecessary confusion and trouble to tax workers, researchers and advisers within and outside the Taxation Office. A decision of a court—for example, Snowden and Willson, Myer Emporium—everywhere is reported under the same name and is easily and quickly found in any alphabetical table of cases. But if one is given the Butterworths reference to an AAT decision and one has access only to CCH reports, or vice versa, then finding the case involves a time-wasting search through conversion tables, verifications, et cetera. Communication between tax workers is also made more difficult. If a tax adviser is `speaking in Butterworths' to an ATO officer or another adviser who is `speaking in CCH', or vice versa, then time may be wasted on both sides while the necessary adjustments are made.

Anyone involved in writing and publishing on tax matters is put to unnecessary trouble and expense in providing dual citations. This applies not only to the law publishers but also, among others, to the Taxation Office itself, whose officers are writing letters of advice, drafting rulings and so on. These changes can be brought about simply by repealing the present sections—sections 14ZZE and 14ZZJ—which were introduced in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. Several members of the taxation industry asked for this at the time. With the rush of legislation late last year I can understand why this was not dealt with at the time, but it should not be forgotten. This would leave sections 35 and 43 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act to operate without modification.

We appreciate that there are at least two strong arguments for not making this change. They may be expressed as follows. The ATO has consistently and for a very long time taken the view that taxation proceedings in the AAT and in the Taxation Boards of Review before it should be in strict confidence. This is presumably because a taxpayer's affairs are regarded as strictly a matter between the taxpayer and the Commissioner, and perhaps the taxpayer's advisers, and nobody else. When the Taxation Boards of Review were abolished and their jurisdiction transferred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the present sections 14ZF and 14ZK of the Taxation Administration Act were enacted. The explanatory memorandum to the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill explained that it was done in order to preserve the privacy of taxation affairs afforded to persons under existing review procedures.

It can be argued that the process of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision made by the Commissioner is still an integral part of the administrative process of assessing and collecting tax. This argument, which is based on the vital distinction between administration and the judicial function, would provide support for the position that proceedings in the AAT should remain confidential.

These are powerful considerations, but there are countervailing views. When a tax matter is appealed to the Federal Court from the AAT or directly from the objection decision it immediately becomes a public matter and is listed. If it results in a judgment, it is reported under the parties' name unless the court decides otherwise. Yet it is the same matter. Why should it be anonymous at one level of the review and appeals system but public at a higher level? It may be argued that it is only when the appeal from the AAT decision is instituted that the matter leaves the administrative sphere and enters the judicial sphere. If it is important to maintain confidentiality after the AAT stage, what then is the point of giving objectors a free choice in relation to the majority of objection decisions between seeking review by the AAT and appealing directly to the court?

It might also be noted that the administrative function link between the Tax Office and the AAT was weakened when the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 became law, giving objectors the right to apply directly to the AAT or to the Federal Court rather than to ask the ATO to refer the matter forward.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal hears a wide range of cases involving Customs matters, deportation, social security, freedom of information, et cetera, many of which are likely to disclose commercial, financial and personal information that could be just as sensitive as tax information. Yet all these cases are liable to be reported under the parties' names. So far as I am aware, only reviews carried out under the insurance legislation and the occupational superannuation standards legislation share the requirement of confidentiality. Even cases involving the registration of tax agents are reported so that all the world knows the tax agents' names, whether they win or lose. What, in real terms, is the difference?

In addition, section 35 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, if it were allowed to operate in unmodified form in relation to taxation reviews, would provide adequate safeguards for those applicants who might wish to have the confidentiality of their taxation affairs preserved. From the beginning of the system of administrative review of taxpayer-ATO disputes the ATO has insisted that taxpayers' privacy be preserved in public reports of decided cases. Administrative review here means cases heard by the Taxation Appeals Division. This has meant that cases at this level have always been reported by some unique identifier which does not include the names of the parties. This is in contrast to reports of court cases, which almost always are identified by the names of the parties.

From 1922 until 1949, when there was only one Taxation Board of Review, which published its own case reports, there was no real problem. The problem really arose in 1950, when the commercial publishers—Butterworths and the Law Book Company, commonly known as the LBC, and later Butterworths and CCH—took over publication of the Board of Review decisions. The publishers decided to go their separate ways with case identification systems. Butterworths began the series of reports called CTBR(NS); LBC launched a series called TBRD. But the two companies were publishing the same cases. Thus we had the absurd position, when we look at it objectively, in which a given decision by a Board of Review would be published under two separate and independent identifiers. For example, a case published by Butterworths as 7CTBR(NS) Case 48 was published by LBC as Case H47 8 TBRD. It becomes even more absurd when one finds that this case, on appeal to the High Court, becomes Federal Commissioner of Taxation v. Snowden and Willson Pty Ltd, under which name, of course, both Butterworths and LBC published it. When CCH took over the Law Book Company's tax subscriptions around 1968, closed down TBRD and launched ATC in its place, it continued the tradition.

The position has remained the same to this day. When the taxation boards of review were abolished and their jurisdiction transferred to the newly created Taxation Appeals Division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, section 35 of the AAT Act, which specifically provides for public hearings, was modified by section 14ZF of the Taxation Administration Act so that hearings before the new Division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be private, unless the taxpayer requested otherwise.

Likewise, section 43 of the AAT Act was modified by section 14ZK of the Taxation Administration Act. This is why we report AAT cases as AAT Case 4120 (1990) 21 ATR, et cetera, while CCH calls them Case W21 90 ATC, et cetera. I believe that the solution lies in allowing the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to hold taxation hearings in public unless the applicant opts for a private hearing, instead of the other way around; that is, the hearing of taxation matters and the publication of taxation decisions would be in conformity with virtually all the other matters in which the AAT has jurisdiction. I look forward to hearing from either the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, or Senator Evans, who is skilled in the knowledge of the law and would be aware of the confusion arising from this dual publication. I look forward to Senator Evans's comments on the matters that have been raised tonight.
