TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of some time this evening to expand upon a matter that I have been pursuing in this place for some months now, and that is the limestone quarry at Exit Cave near Lune River in southern Tasmania. In the early 1950s, limestone quarrying started at the Exit Cave area and it has continued since. In 1983, amid a great amount of jubilation and fanfare, the Australian Labor Government acted under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to stop the proceeding of the Franklin Dam. Later, it stopped rainforest logging in the Queensland wet tropics World Heritage area.

PARA.TAB: Following this flurry of activity, in May 1988 the Helsham Commission recommended the nomination of Exit Cave for World Heritage listing. I will quote from a document which was essentially a heads of agreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmania, known as the Cook-Groom 29 November 1988 heads of agreement, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth agrees that the operation of Benders quarry within the Exit cave area nominated for World Heritage listing can continue provided that acceptable limits are set to the scale and development of the operation. Should any financial loss result from any limits placed on the operation, the Commonwealth will pay compensation direct to the company concerned.

World Heritage listing was achieved in December 1989. It has been acknowledged by the environmental management plan drawn up by Benders, and by both the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments as indicated by the Cook agreement, that the quarry is within the World Heritage area.

PARA.TAB: In November 1991, Exit Quarry was proven to have an impact on the World Heritage values of the Exit Cave system. This is according to Mr Kevin Kiernan who, in his investigation of the matter, provided information from a hydrogeological report and field survey notes. Subsequently, Benders Pty Ltd prepared an environmental management plan to support its continued operation of the quarry. Public submissions were invited to consider this environmental management plan. I understand that 180 submissions were made by way of objection to the plans in that environment management plan.

On 5 February 1992, Benders was permitted to undertake some blasting under licence conditions that were drawn up by the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning and endorsed by the Commonwealth. Part of the reason for this extra blasting was to provide a sample which would be used by Benders as part of the tendering processes for the supply of limestone to Pasminco Metals-EZ. The question of why this was allowed to happen if the quarry operations had been shown to affect the Exit Cave system is yet to be answered.
On Monday, 24 February, the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee assessed the environmental management plan and concluded as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . past and present quarrying operations have indisputably damaged solution cavities, sink holes and caves that are now known to be part of the Exit Cave karst subsystem.
Further, it concluded:
. . . and that even under the strictest environmental conditions continuing of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values.

This conclusion was to be used at a meeting of the ministerial council scheduled to meet on or before 29 February but which was postponed by a request of Minister Cleary, the Tasmanian Government's environment Minister. This ministerial council has yet to meet since that postponement.

PARA.TAB: It is clear, and it became clear to me this morning from his statements on the ABC radio in Hobart, that Mr Cleary accepts the conclusion of the Standing Committee. It is also clear from his comments on the ABC radio in Hobart this morning that he is concerned about compensation and finding an alternative to the limestone which is quarried at Exit Cave. They are legitimate concerns and concerns with which we would agree. However, they should not stand in the way of any decision which should be taken to close the existing quarrying operations.

The question of compensation lies clearly within the agreement of 1988 that I have already quoted from between Senator Cook and Mr Ray Groom, who is now the Premier of Tasmania. The question of the supply of limestone is a proper consideration, but it is not one to delay this decision. In fact, I cannot understand why the State Minister continues to procrastinate.

On 6 March in Hobart's Mercury newspaper, Mr Cleary asked all parties to refrain from public comment until the ministerial council meeting took place, suggesting that such comments so far were uninformed and that they could jeopardise negotiations for a satisfactory solution. However, today on Hobart's ABC radio he claimed that he needs further information about compensation. As I said before, and as I quoted previously, the answer to that question is presented in a straightforward way in black and white in the Cook-Groom heads of agreement which says that compensation shall be paid by the Commonwealth to any affected parties. I suggest that in this case it is not me who is uninformed and it is not me who should refrain from further public comment. Rather, the State Minister, Mr Cleary, has chosen to remain uninformed and ignore what is set out in black and white in the Cook-Groom heads of agreement.

Another case of claimed uncertainty concerns the question of the existence of a contract. This question could have a direct bearing on the existence, or certainly the level, of compensation which may be negotiated. The question of the existence of a contract, which should be central to the degree or level of compensation, has to some extent been enlightened by correspondence that I have engaged in with Mr Paul Salmon, the General Manager of Operations of Pasminco Metals-EZ.

I engaged in correspondence with Mr Salmon because there appeared to be some doubt about the existence or non-existence of a contract. Minister Ros Kelly was informed in a briefing from her Department—her advisers provided me with a copy of it—that on 28 February 1992 Benders had advised it that its contract with Pasminco Metals-EZ had been extended. The renewed contract was to supply approximately 26,000 tonnes yearly—the same tonnage as the recent contract—until June 1994. That advice was given to Minister Kelly. It seems strange to me that 28 February was the same day that Minister Cleary asked that the Ministerial Council meeting be postponed. Minister Kelly agreed to that. It seems strange to me that there was talk of a contract existing as of that date. To clarify that matter, I wrote to Mr Paul Salmon. My letter, dated 10 March 1992, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: You may have heard of a rumour that Pasminco Metals has recently renewed a contract with Benders for the supply of 26 000 tonnes of limestone.

PARA.TAB: I have subsequently heard that this is not the case. However in view of the importance of the issue of Exit Cave's protection I would appreciate:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.An assurance that no written or verbal contract has been entered into by your company; and
2.An assurance that Pasminco will not enter into any written or verbal arrangement with Benders to supply limestone until the Ministerial Council has resolved the future of the quarry at Exit Cave.

PARA.TAB: You are probably aware that I have received a briefing paper from the Minister to which I will need to respond today. Your comments as soon as possible would be helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: On 12 March 1992 I received a correspondence from Mr Salmon. The letter stated:
Dear Senator,

PARA.TAB: I am writing in response to your letter of 10 March 1992 seeking information on the supply of limestone to our Hobart refinery.
As you are probably aware, the existing supply contract with Benders Pty Ltd expires on 30 June 1992.
In line with normal procedure, Pasminco Metals EZ called tenders for a new supply contract to operate from that date. No contract has been signed.

However, after full consideration of supply proposals, it was indicated to Benders that Pasminco Metals EZ was prepared to enter a new agreement with that company subject to Benders having a secure source of supply that meets all legal and regulatory requirements.

I wish to make it absolutely clear that Pasminco Metals EZ will under no circumstances take any action that would conflict with any decision of the Ministerial Council considering the future of the Exit Cave quarry.
On the issue of limestone supplies, Pasminco Metals EZ is co-operating fully with Federal and State authorities to ensure the most satisfactory solution for all parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely,
Paul Salmon
General Manager Operations

I conclude from that, again, that I am not the one who is uninformed in making comments about this; rather, it is those who have chosen to ignore this correspondence which I have made public and which clearly states the situation with regard to the contract or, in fact, the lack of a contract. Mr Salmon has advised that no contract has been signed.

PARA.TAB: We have a State Minister who would like the discussion to go away, leaving him in peace and quiet. In fact, the situation is quite clear and leaves the Federal Minister little opportunity to do anything other than to expedite the decision on this and to follow through the Government's obligation to do all in its power to protect the areas it nominates for listing.

For the Minister to sit idly by, like Nero outside burning Rome, while quarrying operations continue to eat away at the fundamental values for which the area was nominated for world recognition in the first place is ministerial irresponsibility of the kind that has led to decades of environmental neglect and decay in this and other countries. I believe it is time that this matter was put to rest. There is a long history there. I have taken enough of the Senate's time in delineating some of it. I think it is time that it was concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the review that is being conducted into the taxation treatment of the payment of PAYE and fringe benefits tax of local government councillors to determine what arrangements are appropriate in the future, as announced by the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 February 1990:
(1) Do the vast majority of councillors work in a voluntary capacity and therefore can not be compared with paid Members of Parliament, members of State authorities or company directors.
(2) Are meals, refreshments and entertainment required components of attendance at council meetings and the performance of civic duties and thus are not fringe benefits.

(3) As councillors are prevented by legislation in most States from taking on paid employment in councils and thus are specifically prohibited from assuming `employee' status in councils, would it be fair and equitable to force councillors to pay fringe benefits tax and have PAYE tax instalments deducted from their council allowances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In the former Treasurer's Press Release No. 82 of 5 September 1991, Mr Kerin announced that the review of taxation arrangements for local government councillors has been completed and that the Government has decided to leave the tax situation unchanged. That is, local government councils will remain free of any fringe benefits tax liability for benefits provided to councillors. Also, councillors will not be subject to the tax instalment (PAYE) provisions on their remuneration and allowances, nor the substantiation provisions in respect of employment related expenses, related to their council duties.

In accordance with existing income tax law, remuneration received by councillors (whether in the form of cash allowances or benefits in kind) is assessable in their hands. Thus, councillors will be assessed on the value of benefits such as cars provided by councils for private use by councillors. The remuneration is subject to the provisional tax provisions.

While councillors are not subject to the income tax substantiation requirements relating to employment related expenses associated with carrying out their council duties, such expenses are deductible only where the expenditure is incurred in gaining or producing assessable income. The substantiation requirements relating to `car expenses' and `travel expenses' will continue to apply.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the application of Section 6AA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, covering the tax payable by resident minors which has not reflected a general lowering of the tax rates, is it anomalous to continue applying a tax rate of 66 per cent on income between $417 and $1,445 when the top marginal rate is now 47 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: No. The special rates of tax applicable to the eligible income of minors under Division 6AA of the Income Tax Assessment Act apply to unearned income and are intended to discourage income splitting by directing income to minors.

The special rates apply to eligible taxable income in excess of $416 per annum. The unearned income of minors is taxed at a rate of 47 per cent where that income exceeds $1,445 per annum. Where unearned income exceeds $416 but is less than $1,445, a rate of 66 per cent is applied to the amount of unearned income in excess of $416.

Under this arrangement the tax burden of minors with unearned income between $416 and $1,445 remains less than 47 per cent and there is a gradual transition to the 47 per cent tax rate. The effect of the arrangement is to reduce the benefit of the threshold for minors with unearned income above $416 per annum.

(3) Is it correct that Telecom is seeking to contest Mr Moffatt's appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of Telecom's decision to refuse compensation.

(4) Has Telecom sought to deny compensation on the basis of a claim pursuant to s.5(9) of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988; if so, and if the claim is upheld, will the Minister undertake to amend the Act to overcome this anomaly.
(5) Does the Minister have the power to order Telecom to grant an ex-gratia compassionate payment to Mr Moffat; if so, would the Minister consider this course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I regret the delay in replying to the letters from the Asbestos Diseases Society of Australia. Mr Moffat's claim for compensation is a very complex matter. However, my Department has been investigating the issues as a matter of priority, together with the Attorney General's Department and the Department of Industrial Relations. I will respond to the Asbestos Diseases Society as soon as all relevant issues have been fully clarified.

(2) I am advised that Comcare considers that subsection 7(1) of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 to be a "reverse onus of proof" provision the effect of which is to entitle an employee to compensation if he or she has contracted a disease that is specified as being related to a particular aspect of employment in which the employee was engaged, unless the employer can establish that the contraction of the disease was not contributed to by that employment.

By notice published in the Gazette on 30 November 1988, the then Minister for Social Security specified "lung cancer or mesothelioma caused by asbestos" and "employment involving exposure to asbestos" as a disease and its related type of employment for the purposes of subsection 7(1).
However a definitive opinion on the interpretation of s.7(1) has been sought from the Attorney-General's Department by the Department of Industrial Relations.

(3) Telecom did challenge Mr Moffat's application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and lodged an appeal against the decision to the Federal Court. It has advised that an interim payment of $15,000 was made to Mr Moffat pending the outcome of this appeal. On 28 February the Federal Court handed down a decision in favour of Mr Moffat and I understand that all monies to which Mr Moffat was entitled were paid to Mr Moffat by Telecom the following working day, 2 March 1992.
Telecom may decide to ask a Higher Court for leave to appeal against the decision of the Federal Court, depending on their own legal advice.

(4) Telecom advised that at the hearing at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, one of the bases upon which it challenged the application made by Mr Moffat, was that at the time he sustained the alleged injury, he was not an employee of Telecom. Telecom relied on s.5(9) of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 to advance the submission. However the claim by Telecom was not upheld.
(5) The outcome of the proceedings in the Federal Court was in favour of Mr Moffat. The Federal Court's decision means that the question of an ex-gratia payment is no longer relevant.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Transport in Rural and Remote Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, upon notice, on 3 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Government response to the recommendations of the `Transport in Rural and Remote Australia Conference' in Alice Springs, on 24-26 March 1991, made public on 8 July 1991:
(1) What budget initiatives arising from the Government response have been implemented to date.
(2) What are future budgetary implications.
(3) What is the current status of the data base being developed by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (BTCE) regarding the condition and capacity of the National Highway Scheme.

(4) Have the Federal Office of Road Safety and the National Road Transport Regulatory Commission considered Recommendation 6—`the Federal Government consider the need for a review of the suitability of existing vehicle design and manufacturing standards for rural and remote Australia'; if so, what did their investigation find.

(5) What is the status of investigations by the BTCE and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) into the implications to rural and remote Australia of changes to road user charging arrangements and have any reports by BTCE or ABARE been made available to the department; if so, can they be made available to the Senate.

(6) Has the BTCE completed studies on the community service obligation component in the provision of road infrastructure and rail services; if not, when is it anticipated to be completed; if so, can a copy be made available and when is the Government likely to respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia have provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government's concerns for Australians dwelling in rural and remote areas are reflected in a number of initiatives recently announced.

In the Prime Minister's "One Nation" statement of 26 February, it was announced that over $1 billion would be allocated to land transport improvements. This included $603 million for roads which will generate an additional 15,000 person years of employment: many of the jobs will be in rural Australia.

Also included in the Prime Minister's statement were funds to assist the redevelopment of Tennant Creek's business centre, an extra $6 million for the Kakadu Highway, an additional $5 million for the Victoria Highway, upgrading of the Kalgoorlie-Meekatharra and Port Hedland-Marble Bar roads, and additional funds for road works in north west Queensland.

At the 30 July 1991 Special Premiers' Conference, Heads of Government agreed to establish a National Road Transport Commission (NRTC) to develop and implement national arrangements for registration, regulation and charging of vehicles over 4.5 tonnes.
The NRTC is required under its legislation to consult with the representatives of people who live in remote areas of Australia in developing its recommendations.

(2) At this stage it is difficult to forecast future budgetary implications for the NRTC. Depending on the future scope of the NRTC's responsibilities (e.g. whether light vehicles are included), subsequent budget allocations should be of a similar magnitude to the 1991-92 contribution.

(3) The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (BTCE) has national highway information which includes road widths, surface type and traffic and is based on the status of the system as at July 1990. The data was provided to the BTCE by the state road authorities to enable the national highway system to be analysed. The Bureau expects to release a publication by April this year which will present that data in useable form.
(4) The National Road Transport Commission has only recently been established and has not had the opportunity to consider this matter.

The Federal Office of Road Safety has reviewed the points presented in the conference report. To provide more information on this subject the Office last year commissioned a study of crashes in rural and remote areas.

The study is co-sponsored by Victoria, Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australia. Queensland's University of Technology has been contracted to conduct a literature search and an analysis of crash databases in the four sponsoring States as well as the Federal databases. A draft report is expected in April of this year.

Australian Design Rules form the safety standards applied to vehicle manufacturers. These Design Rules are largely based on international standards which, in turn, are developed by authorities representing a very wide range of transport conditions. The Design Rules are formulated by an advisory committee which includes representatives from vehicle user groups and consumer groups as well as the Governments of each State and Territory and the vehicle manufacturers. Diverging from these international standards will increase costs for vehicles sold here irrespective of their country of origin.

The needs of remote Australia are not neglected in the Committee's deliberations. Any proposed Design Rule amendment is circulated for public comment so that a wider range of views can be considered. Any suggestions to enhance safety are considered in that process.
So far, the broad based consultative procedures have not identified any specific vehicle design safety features which are not already addressed in the Design Rules.

Vehicle manufacturers who sell vehicles into remote areas are particularly conscious of consumer preferences regarding durability. Remote Australia is often used to test the durability of a new vehicle design prior to production commencing. It is clearly in the manufacturer's interests to take account of their own testing and customer feedback to help improve the product. The mechanisms already in place provide a sound basis for this.

(5) Studies by the BTCE and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE), on the implications for rural and remote areas of changes to road user charging, are underway. The date proposed for completion of this work is April 1992. As soon as the report is complete it will be made available to me. A BTCE paper based on earlier work and prepared for the Transport in Rural and Remote Areas Conference held in Alice Springs in March 1991 is available.

(6) The BTCE is currently undertaking a study of community service obligations in road infrastructure. A paper will be provided to AUSTROADS for their meeting in April. A draft of that paper was discussed at a Bureau workshop on road community service obligations on 14 February. Work on the study of rail community service obligations will not be commenced until after completion of the road study. It is expected that the results from the two studies will be published early next year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the extent and nature of Australia's military and defence association with Indonesia, including military aid, defence equipment, military transfers and defence cooperation.
(2) What are the legal foundations for such associations.
(3) What was the monetary cost to Australia of this association for 1990-91 and what is the forecast of such cost for 1991-92.
(4) What guarantees has the Australian Government received that no defence equipment from Australia has been used by Indonesia in military operations in East Timor.
(5) Does the military training provided by Australia to Indonesian defence personnel include information on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Geneva Conventions.
(6) Was the subject of human rights raised in discussions with Indonesia's General Try Sutrisno during his recent visit to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia does not provide military "aid" to Indonesia. Australia and Indonesia undertake a range of cooperative defence activities, all of which are jointly funded. Areas of mutual priority include attendance at Staff Colleges, logistics cooperation, maritime surveillance cooperation, Naval exercises, and training in a wide range of technical and military disciplines. These activities emphasise practical cooperation that is of mutual benefit and which develop personal and professional relationships.
Since the Defence Cooperation Program (DCP) was terminated in 1988, no defence equipment has been given to Indonesia.
Australia has sold some defence equipment to Indonesia commercially. The following permits for export have been issued since 1989:
4.5 inch ammunition and practice ammunition for naval guns ($1,765,661) commercial explosives for seismic purposes ($204,000) cryptographic equipment ($13,939)
2 Pratt and Whitney engines for DC3 aircraft and spares for F404 and T700 engines ($250,000) commercial explosives for mining purposes ($126,027)
(2) These associations are conducted in the context of the Commonwealth's Constitutional responsibilities for foreign affairs and defence.
(3) During 1990-91 expenditure from Division 232, Defence Cooperation, was $0.53 million. The current amount allocated from Division 232 for 1991-92 is $2.003 million.

Defence Cooperation funding has been used to fund the Australian contribution to a range of cooperative activities with Indonesia. The Australian component of activities such as ships and aircraft visits and combined exercises are funded from the relevant Service.
(4) Australia has not provided any arms, ammunition or equipment to Indonesia which would be directly relevant to the kind of military operations conducted in East Timor.

(5) We do not include separate lectures on human rights in our military courses. Australia is a party to the two International Covenants which followed on from the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights and to the Geneva Conventions of 12, August 1949 and the two Protocols of 8 June 1977 which followed. Australian military training meets all international requirements with respect to the observance of human rights. Respect of human rights is an integral part of Australia's military training, including training provided to all other countries.
(6) I am not aware of such subjects being discussed with General Try Sutrisno during his visit to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 13 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) For which jet aircraft, if any, is Longreach considered a possible emergency landing strip.
(2) In respect of any jet aircraft for which Longreach is not considered an appropriate emergency landing strip, what is the nearest suitable emergency landing strip.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no agreed definition of an emergency landing strip. An aircraft in distress may need to attempt a landing at any available aerodrome. The final decision rests with the pilot in command, who will take into account the nature of the emergency, the requirement (if any) for an immediate landing, and the performance characteristics of the aircraft. In assessing the suitability of an aerodrome, the pilot in command will be primarily influenced by the adequacy of the runway(s), the navigational and landing aids available and the prevailing weather conditions. He or she may also consider the availability of rescue and fire fighting services.

Longreach aerodrome would be suitable under most circumstances for emergency use by aircraft of less than Boeing 727 size. This would include aircraft such as Boeing 737 and A320 as well as a variety of smaller jets which would be able to use Longreach on a routine basis, albeit with a pavement concession.

(2) For aircraft of B727 size and above, there are a number of major aerodromes roughly equidistant from Longreach, such as Mount Isa, Townsville, Hamilton Island, Proserpine and Rockhampton. The closest is Townsville, which is 286 nautical miles or 530 kilometres away.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) The frequency and type of aircraft using Longreach Airport during the Jindalee construction phase will vary but current indications are that there will be approximately 12 flights per month, ranging from light aircraft (less than 10 passengers) to medium size (15-25 passengers); using civilian aircraft in the main.

(2) and (3) The main construction phase will last for about two and a half years and after that there would be one or two light aircraft movements per month until radar acceptance in June 1997 (civilian aircraft). TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What would be the full year cost in 1990-91 dollars of including Australian merchant mariners of World War I (WWI) and World War II (WWII) as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, as recommended by the 1989 McGirr Report.

(2) With reference to an answer to a Question on Notice No. 1170 (Senate Weekly Hansard, 8 October 1991, p.1613) it is stated that the net cost to the Commonwealth of granting the SPBC to Commonwealth and Allied veterans had been revised from the 1989 McGirr Report figure of $18.2 million to $49.25 million, is this increase of 171 per cent attributable only to increases in the average cost of providing treatment and a higher than expected potentially eligible 1991 population; if not, what else is included.

(3) Why, by comparison, was the increase evident in the revised costing relating to the inclusion of Australian merchant mariners of WWI and WWII under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 not nearly so pronounced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (2) The revised net cost reflects increases in average treatment costs and changes in the numbers potentially eligible, but also uses a different basis for cost offsets against other Commonwealth outlays. The McGirr Report included an element for the transfer of hospital costs from Medicare to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. However, because of the nature of the Commonwealth-State hospital agreements, the cost savings would not occur.
(3) In the revised costing, increased unit treatment costs are offset by a revised estimate of the claim take up rate and thus fewer potential treatment recipients.

The proportionally smaller increase also reflects the fact that treatment costs are just one element in the total cost of including Australian mariners of WWI and WWII as veterans under the VEA. Approximately 30% of the total is attributable to pension costs. In this respect offsets in DSS pensions were included in the revised costing.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 February 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why was a 21 gun salute fired in Canberra on 27 January 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Artillery saluted in honour of the official birthday of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and Australia Day are fired at noon on the actual day of the anniversary but, when this occasion falls on a Sunday, the salute is fired at noon on the following day. Accordingly, as Australia Day fell on Sunday 26 January 1992, the Artillery salute was fired on Monday 27 January 1992.
